Austria became a member of the European Union in 1995, and has retained its constitutional neutrality.
TEXT.French: [TAB]L'Autriche a été d'abord colonisée par diverses tribus celtes. Norique, un royaume celtique, a été revendiqué par l'Empire romain et a fait une province. Après la chute de l'empire romain, l'Autriche a été envahie par les Bavarois, les Slaves, et les Avars. Lorsque Charlemagne a conquis les terres de 788, il a encouragé la colonisation et le christianisme. Autriche, qui fait maintenant partie de l'Est Francia, était sous le contrôle de la maison de Babenberg. En 976, la région connue sous le nom de Marchia Orientalis a été donnée à Léopold de Babenberg à 976. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Le premier album de la terre étant connue sous le nom de l'Autriche est en 966 lorsqu'il se réfère au territoire de la Babenberg mars. Les siècles suivants, se caractérisent par des premiers établissements du pays. En 1156, le Privilegium Moins élevée à l'Autriche le duché de statues. Les Babenberg également obtenu le duché de Styrie en 1192. [PARAGRAPH: 2] À la mort de Frédéric II en 1246, a pris fin le Barenberg ligne. Otakar II de Bohême effectivement contrôlé les duchés de l'Autriche. Après sa défaite et Durnkrut par Rudolf I de l'Allemagne en 1278, son règne a pris fin. Les siècles suivants, va marquer une époque de prospérité autrichienne, sous la dynastie au pouvoir, les Habsbourg. Au quatorzième et quinzième siècles, les Habsbourg accumulé provinces dans le domaine de la Duché de l'Autriche. En 1438, le duc Albert V de l'Autriche a été choisi pour succéder à son père dans la loi, l'empereur Sigismond. Bien que Albert a statué que pour un an, à partir de ce moment, chaque empereur du Saint Empire romain était un Habsbourg, à une exception près. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Les Habsbourg ont commencé à accumuler des terres au fil des ans, et en 1477 l'archiduc Maximilien acquis la plupart des pays à faible marient après l'héritière de la Bourgogne. Son fils Philippe le Bel mariée l'héritière de Castille et d'Aragon et de l'acquisition de l'Espagne et de ses italienne, africaine et du Nouveau Monde compléments pour les Habsbourg. [PARAGRAPH: 2] À la suite de la bataille de Mohacs, autrichien dirigeants élargi leur territoire. Toutefois, l'expansion ottomane en Hongrie a conduit à de fréquents conflits entre les deux pouvoirs. Le long règne de Léopold Ier d'Autriche a mis fin au conflit avec les Turcs. Suite à la défense de Vienne en 1628, une série de campagnes abouti au retour de la Hongrie à autrichien de contrôle en 1699. Toutefois, au cours de la dernière partie du règne de l'empereur Charles VI, Autriche annulé certains de ces gains. Après cette période, l'âge du dualisme austro-hongrois de Prusse a débuté en Hongrie. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Divers défaites contre Napoléon fut la fin de l'ancien Saint Empire romain germanique en 1806, et en 1804 l'Empire autrichien a été fondée. En 1867, il a été transformé en la double monarchie austro-hongroise. Suivant les guerres napoléoniennes, l'Autriche est apparue comme l'une des puissances dominantes de l'Europe avec la Prusse et la Russie. En 1815, la Confédération allemande a été fondé sous la présidence de l'Autriche. L'Autriche et la Prusse étaient l'une des deux principales puissances. Après l'Allemagne souhaitait devenir un pays unifié, l'Autriche n'était pas disposée à devenir une partie de celui-ci et est née de l'Allemagne, tandis que la Prusse a grandi dans lui. Après la défaite de la Prusse à la bataille de Koniggratz la Bohême, l'Autriche a dû quitter la Confédération allemande et a été par la suite ne sont plus autorisés à prendre part à la politique allemande. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Le compromis austro-hongrois de 1867 a fourni une double souveraineté sous Franz Joseph I, qui a gouverné jusqu'à sa mort. La diversité de l'empire fait qu'il est difficile de maîtriser à l'âge de l'émergence des mouvements nationalistes. L'assassinat de l'archiduc Franz Ferdinand en 1914 a été la cause la plus probable de la première guerre mondiale, qui a conduit à la chute de l'Empire austro-hongrois. [PARAGRAPH: 2] En 1918 et 1919, l'Autriche a été connu sous le nom de la République de l'Autriche allemande. La monarchie a cependant été dissous en 1919 et une démocratie parlementaire a été créée en 1920. En 1922, l'Autriche a reçu un prêt pour améliorer la situation économique générale. Avec l'octroi du prêt, de l'Autriche transmise d'un État indépendant pour le contrôle exercé par la Société des Nations. À l'époque, le véritable souverain de l'Autriche est devenue la Ligue, par l'intermédiaire de son commissaire à Vienne. [PARAGRAPH: 2] La Première République autrichienne a duré jusqu'en 1933. Les deux principaux partis se sont battues au sein du parlement. Après la guerre civile autrichienne en 1934, plusieurs membres de la Schutzbund Parti ont été exécutés et le Parti social démocrate a été proscrit. En 1936, les troupes allemandes occupent le pays et Hitler, natif de l'Autriche a lui-même perdu la citoyenneté en 1925. Juste avant l'effondrement du IIIe Reich, Karl Renner, mettre en place un gouvernement provisoire à Vienne. Tout comme l'Allemagne, l'Autriche, elle aussi, été divisé en un britannique, le français, l'un soviétique et une zone américaine et qui sont régies par la Commission alliée de l'Autriche. [PARAGRAPH: 2] En mai 1955, l'Autriche a retrouvé l'indépendance et s'est déclaré perpétuellement neutre, dont il demeure aujourd'hui. Le système politique de la Deuxième République est venu à être caractérisée par le système de Proporz, ce qui signifie que la plupart des postes de certaines politiques importantes ont été répartis de manière égale entre les membres de la sociaux-démocrates et le Parti populaire. Aujourd'hui, l'Autriche a cinq grands partis: le SPO (Parti travailliste), le RPV (conservateurs), les Verts (écologistes) et FPÖ (nationalistes). L'Autriche est devenue membre de l'Union européenne en 1995, et a conservé sa neutralité constitutionnelle.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Österreich wurde zum ersten Mal die von verschiedenen keltischen Stämmen. Noricum, eines keltischen Königreiches, wurde behauptet durch das römische Reich und machte eine Provinz. Nach dem Fall des römischen Reiches, Österreich wurde erobert von Bayern, Slawen und Awaren. Wenn Charlemagne erobert das Land in 788, er ermutigt Kolonisation und Christentum. Österreich, jetzt Teil der östlichen Francia, wurde unter der Kontrolle des Hauses der Babenberger. In 976, in den Bereich bekannt als Marchia Orientalis wurde auf der Babenberger Leopold in der 976. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Die erste Erwähnung des Landes, bekannt als Österreich ist in 966, wenn sie auf dem Gebiet der Babenberger März. Die folgenden Jahrhunderte sind gekennzeichnet durch den frühen Siedlungen des Landes. In 1156, das Privilegium Minus erhöhten Österreich auf das Herzogtum Statuen. Die Babenberger gewann auch das Herzogtum Steiermark 1192. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Mit dem Tod Friedrichs II. in 1246, die Barenberg Zeile endete. Otakar II. von Böhmen wirksam kontrolliert die Herzogtümer Österreich. Nach seiner Niederlage und Durnkrut von Rudolf I. von Deutschland in 1278, seiner Herrschaft zu Ende. Die folgenden Jahrhunderte würde eine Zeit der österreichischen Wohlstand, unter den herrschenden Dynastie der Habsburger. In der vierzehnten und fünfzehnten Jahrhundert, die Habsburger kumulierten Provinzen in der Gegend des Herzogtums Österreich. In 1438, Herzog Albrecht V. von Österreich wurde als Nachfolger von seinem Schwiegervater, Kaiser Sigismund. Obwohl Albert entschieden, für die nur ein Jahr, von diesem Zeitpunkt an, alle Kaiser des Heiligen Römischen Reiches war ein Habsburger, mit einer Ausnahme. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Die Habsburger begann zu akkumulieren landet im Laufe der Jahre, und in 1477 die Erzherzog Maximilian erworben meisten der Niederen Länder nach der Heirat der Erbin von Burgund. Sein Sohn Philipp der Schöne heiratete die Erbin von Kastilien und Aragon, und der Übernahme von Spanien und seine italienische, afrikanische, und New World Hilfsmittel für die Habsburger. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Nach der Schlacht bei Mohacs, der österreichischen Herrscher ihre Territorien. Allerdings ist die Expansion des Osmanischen Reiches in Ungarn führte zu häufigen Konflikten zwischen den beiden Mächten. Die lange Herrschaft von Leopold I. endete der österreichischen Konflikt mit den Türken. Im Anschluss an die Verteidigung von Wien 1628, eine Reihe von Kampagnen in die Rückkehr der Ungarn in die österreichische Control im 1699. Aber, während der zweiten Hälfte der Regierungszeit von Kaiser Karl VI, Österreich verzichtet einige dieser Gewinne. Nach Ablauf dieser Zeit, im Alter von der österreichischen preußischen Dualismus begann in Ungarn. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Verschiedene Niederlagen gegen Napoleon schreibt das Ende des alten Heiligen Römischen Reiches 1806, und in 1804 der österreichischen Reiches gegründet. In 1867 wurde es in der doppelten - Monarchie Österreich - Ungarn. Im Anschluss an die Napoleonischen Kriege, Österreich als einer von Europa's beherrschenden Kräfte zusammen mit Preußen und Russland. In 1815, der deutsche Bund wurde unter dem Vorsitz von Österreich. Österreich und Preußen waren einer der beiden führenden Mächte. Nach Deutschland wollte sich ein einheitliches Land, in Österreich nicht bereit war, zum Teil von ihm und wuchs aus Deutschland, während sie in Preußen wuchs. Nach der Niederlage der Preußen in der Schlacht bei Koniggratz in Böhmen, Österreich verlassen mussten die Deutschen Bundes und wurde in der Folge nicht mehr gestattet, die Teilnahme an der deutschen Politik. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Die Österreichisch-Ungarische Ausgleich "von 1867, die eine doppelte Souveränität unter Franz Joseph I., regierte bis zu seinem Tod. Die Vielfalt des Reiches machte es schwer, in einem Zeitalter der neuen nationalistischen Bewegungen. Die Ermordung von Erzherzog Franz Ferdinand im 1914 war die wahrscheinliche Ursache des Ersten Weltkriegs, die den Untergang der österreichisch-ungarischen Reiches. [PARAGRAPH: 2] In 1918 und 1919, Österreich war bekannt als die der deutschen Republik Österreich. Die Monarchie war jedoch aufgelöst in 1919 und eine parlamentarische Demokratie, wurde im 1920. In 1922, Österreich wurde ein Darlehen zur Verbesserung der allgemeinen wirtschaftlichen Zustand. Mit der Gewährung des Darlehens, die aus Österreich ein unabhängiger Staat auf die Kontrolle durch die Liga der Nationen. Zu der Zeit, die wirkliche Herrscher von Österreich wurde die Liga, durch seine Kommissare in Wien. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Die Erste österreichische Republik dauerte bis 1933. Die beiden großen Parteien bekämpften sich innerhalb des Parlaments. Nach dem österreichischen Bürgerkrieg 1934, mehrere Mitglieder der Schutzbund Partei hingerichtet wurden und die Sozialdemokratische Partei wurde verboten. In 1936, die deutschen Truppen besetzten das Land und Hitler, der in Österreich selbst, verloren Staatsbürgerschaft in 1925. Kurz vor dem Zusammenbruch des Dritten Reiches, Karl Renner, eine provisorische Regierung in Wien. Ähnlich wie in Deutschland, Österreich, zu, wurde in eine britische, französische, sowjetische und eine amerikanische Zone und durch die Alliierten Kommission für Österreich. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Im Mai 1955, Österreich seine Unabhängigkeit und erklärte sich ständig neutrale, die sie noch heute. Das politische System der Zweiten Republik kam zu zeichnen sich durch das System der Proporz, was bedeutet, dass die meisten Beiträge einiger politischer Bedeutung waren geteilter gleichmäßig zwischen den Mitgliedern der Sozialdemokraten und der Volkspartei. Heute hat Österreich fünf großen Parteien: die SPO (Labour Party), die OVP (Konservativen), die Grünen (Umweltschützer), und FPO (Nationalisten). Österreich als Mitglied der Europäischen Union in 1995, und hat sich ihrem verfassungsmäßigen Neutralität.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]L'Austria è stata risolta da varie tribù celtiche. Noricum, un regno celtica, è stato rivendicato da Romano e di fatto una provincia. Dopo la caduta del Romano Impero, l'Austria è stata invasa da bavaresi, slavi, e Avari. Quando Carlo Magno conquista della terra in 788, ha incoraggiato la colonizzazione e il cristianesimo. Austria, ora parte della Francia orientale, è stata sotto il controllo della casa di Babenberg. Nel 976, la zona nota come Marchia Orientalis è stato dato a Leopoldo di Babenberg nel 976. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Il primo record del terreno essendo noto come l'Austria è nel 966, quando fa riferimento al territorio della Babenberg marzo. Secoli successivi sono caratterizzati dai primi insediamenti del paese. Nel 1156, il Privilegium meno elevati per l'Austria il ducato statue. Il Babenbergs anche ottenuto il Ducato di Stiria nel 1192. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Con la morte di Federico II nel 1246, si è conclusa la Barenberg linea. Otakar II di Boemia efficacemente controllato la ducati d'Austria. Dopo la sua sconfitta e Durnkrut da Rudolf I della Germania nel 1278, il suo regno è venuto a scadenza. Secoli successivi sarebbe un tempo di prosperità austriaco, sotto la dinastia, gli Asburgo. Nel XIV e XV secolo, gli Asburgo province accumulato nella zona del Ducato d'Austria. Nel 1438, Albert V duca d'Austria è stato scelto come successore di suo suocero, l'imperatore Sigismondo. Sebbene Albert pronunciata solo per un anno, da quel momento in poi, ogni imperatore del Sacro Romano Impero era un Asburgo, con una sola eccezione. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Il Asburgo ha iniziato ad accumulare terre nel corso degli anni, e nel 1477 l'arciduca Massimiliano acquisito la maggior parte dei Paesi Bassi dopo aver sposato l'erede di Borgogna. Suo figlio Filippo il Bello sposò l'erede di Castiglia e di Aragona, e la Spagna e il suo acquisito italiana, africana, e del Nuovo Mondo adjuncts per gli Asburgo. [PARAGRAPH: 2] In seguito alla battaglia di Mohacs, austriaco governanti ampliato la loro territori. Tuttavia, l'espansione ottomana in Ungheria ha portato a frequenti conflitti tra le due potenze. Il lungo regno di Leopoldo I si è conclusa con l'Austria in conflitto con i Turchi. In seguito alla difesa di Vienna nel 1628, una serie di campagne hanno portato al ritorno di Ungheria per il controllo austriaco nel 1699. Tuttavia, durante l'ultima parte del regno di Carlo VI, l'Austria rinuncia alcuni di questi vantaggi. Trascorso tale termine, l'età del dualismo prussiano austriaca - ha iniziato in Ungheria. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Diversi sconfitte contro Napoleone, la fine del vecchio Sacro Romano Impero nel 1806, e nel 1804 l'impero austriaco è stata fondata. Nel 1867, è stato trasformato in duplice monarchia d'Austria - Ungheria. In seguito le guerre napoleoniche, l'Austria è emersa come una delle potenze dominanti insieme con la Prussia e la Russia. Nel 1815, la Confederazione tedesca è stata fondata, sotto la Presidenza austriaca. Austria e Prussia sono stati uno dei due principali poteri. Dopo la Germania ha voluto diventare un unico paese, l'Austria era disposta a far parte di essa e cresciuto fuori della Germania, mentre è cresciuta in Prussia. In seguito alla sconfitta della Prussia alla battaglia di Koniggratz in Boemia, l'Austria ha dovuto lasciare la Confederazione tedesca ed è stata successivamente non sono più autorizzati a prendere parte politica tedesca. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Il compromesso austro-ungarico del 1867 ha fornito una doppia sovranità sotto Francesco Giuseppe I, che regnò fino alla sua morte. La diversità degli impero reso difficile il controllo in un'epoca di movimenti nazionalisti emergenti. L'assassinio di arciduca Francesco Ferdinando nel 1914 è stata la probabile causa della prima guerra mondiale, che ha portato alle dimissioni della austro-ungarico. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Nel 1918 e 1919, l'Austria era conosciuta come la Repubblica di tedesco in Austria. La monarchia è stata, tuttavia, sciolto nel 1919 e di una democrazia parlamentare è stata istituita nel 1920. Nel 1922, in Austria è stato dato un prestito di migliorare la condizione economica generale. Con la concessione del prestito, l'Austria è passata da uno stato indipendente per il controllo esercitato dalla Lega delle Nazioni. Al momento, il vero sovrano d'Austria è diventata la Lega, attraverso il suo commissario a Vienna. [PARAGRAPH: 2] La Prima Repubblica austriaca è durato fino al 1933. I due principali partiti combattuto reciprocamente, entro il parlamento. Dopo la guerra civile austriaco nel 1934, diversi membri della Schutzbund partito sono stati eseguiti e il Partito socialdemocratico è stato bandito. Nel 1936, le truppe tedesche occupato il paese e di Hitler, un nativo d'Austria se stesso, ha perso la cittadinanza nel 1925. Poco prima del crollo del Terzo Reich, Karl Renner creazione di un governo provvisorio a Vienna. Tanto come la Germania, l'Austria, troppo, è stato diviso in inglese, francese, uno sovietico e uno americano Zona e disciplinato dalla Commissione alleata per l'Austria. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Nel maggio 1955, l'Austria riacquistato l'indipendenza e si è dichiarato neutrale permanente, che rimane oggi. Il sistema politico della seconda Repubblica è venuto a essere caratterizzata dal sistema di Proporz, il che significa che la maggior parte dei posti di qualche importanza politica sono stati divisi equamente tra i membri dei socialdemocratici e il Partito popolare. Oggi, l'Austria ha cinque grandi parti: la SPO (Partito laburista), il OVP (conservatori), i Verdi (ambientalisti), e FPO (nazionalisti). L'Austria è diventata membro dell'Unione europea nel 1995, e ha mantenuto la sua neutralità costituzionale.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Austria fue reiterada por varias tribus celtas. Noricum, un reino celta, que reivindicó el imperio romano e hizo una provincia. Después de la caída del Imperio Romano, Austria fue invadida por los bávaros, eslavos y avaros. Cuando Carlomagno conquistó la tierra en 788, alentó a la colonización y el cristianismo. Austria, que ahora forma parte del este de Francia, estaba bajo el control de la casa de Babenberg. En 976, la zona conocida como Marchia Orientalis fue dado a Leopoldo de Babenberg en 976. [PARAGRAPH: 2] El primer registro de la tierra que es conocido como Austria está en el 966 cuando se refiere al territorio de los Babenberg de marzo. Los siglos siguientes se caracterizan por los primeros asentamientos del país. En 1156, el Privilegium menos elevada de los ducados de Austria a las estatuas. El Babenbergs también obtuvo el Ducado de Estiria en 1192. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Con la muerte de Federico II en 1246, la Barenberg línea terminado. Otakar II de Bohemia efectivamente controlada la duchies de Austria. Después de su derrota y Durnkrut por Rudolf I de Alemania en 1278, su reinado llegó a su fin. Los siguientes siglos se marca una época de prosperidad de Austria, en virtud de la dinastía gobernante, los Habsburgo. En los siglos XIV y XV, los Habsburgo acumulado provincias en la zona del Ducado de Austria. En 1438, el duque Alberto V de Austria fue elegido como sucesor de su suegro, el emperador Segismundo. Aunque Albert gobernó durante sólo un año, a partir de ese momento, todos los emperadores del Sacro Imperio Romano era una Habsburg, con una excepción. [PARAGRAPH: 2] La Habsburgo empezó a acumular tierras a través de los años, y en 1477 el Archiduque Maximiliano adquirido la mayor parte de los Países Bajos después de su matrimonio con la heredera de Borgoña. Su hijo Felipe el Hermoso se casó con la heredera de Castilla y Aragón, y adquirió España y sus italiano, de África, del Nuevo Mundo y complementarios para los Habsburgo. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Después de la Batalla de Mohacs, gobernantes de Austria amplió sus territorios. Sin embargo, la expansión otomana en Hungría dado lugar a frecuentes conflictos entre los dos poderes. El largo reinado de Leopoldo I de Austria en la que terminó el conflicto con los turcos. A raíz de la defensa de Viena en 1628, una serie de campañas se tradujo en el regreso de Hungría para el Control de Austria en 1699. Sin embargo, durante la última parte del reinado del emperador Carlos VI, Austria entregado algunos de esos logros. Después de este tiempo, la edad de dualismo entre Austria y Prusia comenzaron en Hungría. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Diversas derrotas contra Napoleón significó el final del viejo Sacro Imperio Romano en 1806, y en 1804 el Imperio de Austria se fundó. En 1867, se convirtió en la doble monarquía de Austria - Hungría. Después de las guerras Napoleónicas, Austria surgido como una de las potencias dominantes junto con Prusia y Rusia. En 1815, la Confederación Alemana fue fundada bajo la presidencia de Austria. Austria y Prusia fueron una de las dos principales potencias. Después de Alemania desean pasar a ser un país unificado, Austria no estaba dispuesto a convertirse en parte de ella y creció fuera de Alemania, mientras que creció en Prusia. Después de la derrota de Prusia en la batalla de Koniggratz en Bohemia, Austria, tuvo que dejar la Confederación Alemana y posteriormente ya no pueden tomar parte en la política alemana. [PARAGRAPH: 2] La austrohúngara de transacción de 1867 proporcionó una doble soberanía en virtud de Francisco José I, que gobernó hasta su muerte. La diversidad del imperio hizo difícil de controlar en una era de los nuevos movimientos nacionalistas. El asesinato del Archiduque Francisco Fernando en 1914 fue la causa probable de la Primera Guerra Mundial, que llevó a la caída del Imperio Austrohúngaro. [PARAGRAPH: 2] En 1918 y 1919, Austria era conocido como la República de Austria alemana. La monarquía fue, sin embargo, disuelto en 1919 y de una democracia parlamentaria se estableció en 1920. En 1922, Austria se le dio un préstamo para mejorar la condición económica general. Con la concesión del préstamo, Austria pasó de un estado independiente para el control ejercido por la Sociedad de las Naciones. En el momento, el verdadero gobernante de Austria se convirtió en la Liga, a través de su comisionado en Viena. [PARAGRAPH: 2] La Primera República de Austria se prolongó hasta 1933. Los dos partidos principales se enfrentaron en otros en el Parlamento. Después de la Guerra Civil de Austria en 1934, varios miembros de la Schutzbund Partido fueron ejecutados y el Partido Social Demócrata fue prohibido. En 1936, las tropas alemanas ocuparon el país y Hitler, natural de Austria a sí mismo, pierde la ciudadanía en 1925. Justo antes de la caída del Tercer Reich, Karl Renner establecer un Gobierno Provisional en Viena. Mucho como Alemania, Austria, también se divide en un británico, el francés, el soviético y un American Zone y se rige por la Comisión Aliada para Austria. [PARAGRAPH: 2] En mayo de 1955, Austria recuperó su independencia y se declaró neutral permanente, que sigue siendo hoy. El sistema político de la Segunda República llegó a ser caracterizado por el sistema de Proporz, lo que significa que la mayoría de los puestos de algunos importancia política se dividieron por igual entre los miembros de los socialdemócratas y el Partido Popular. Hoy, Austria ha cinco grandes partes: el SPO (Partido Laborista), el OVP (Conservadores), los Verdes (ecologistas), y FPO (nacionalistas). Austria pasó a ser miembro de la Unión Europea en 1995, y ha mantenido su neutralidad constitucional.

TEXT.English: [TAB]"Of all the frontiers of the ancient world, none has endured so long in the poetic imagination as the kingdom of Baktria. In those distant haunts of the Hindu Kush, nearly three thousand miles east of Athens, the Hellenes imagined a never-never land untouched by civilization. Rivers of honey oozed on the Baktrian frontier; fierce griffins guarded the precious gold mined by giant ants; people had ears the size of an elephant's, ate their parents, and lived for centuries." According to tradition, the god Dionysos was the first to tame this land, then Herakles, and finally Alexandros. The realities of the kingdom of Baktria are more difficult to come by however, and the influence of the Iranian peoples played a larger role than the legends reveal. While the history and culture of the kingdom of Baktria is obscured in the mists at its home near the top of the world, it is known that at its largest extent it encompassed an area consisting of all of Turkmenistan, Tadzhikistan, Uzbekistan, Afghanistan, and Pakistan, up to the Indus."[PARAGRAPH:2]The Baktrian Kingdom was founded around 250 BC by the Seleukid King Antiochos II's satrap Diodotos in the region, when he secured his satrapy's independence from the seemingly irresponsible Seleukids. Though Diodotos' reign was relatively free of major emergencies, it was exceedingly brief, and was ended by one of the first internal feuds that characterized Baktrian politics for almost all of it's history.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 230 BC, Diodotos was overthrown and killed by Euthydemos, who managed to secure the kingdom's possessions in the North around Ferghana and Sogdiane. During the first decade of his reign, Euthydemos fought frequently and inconclusively with the Parthians in the West, but reportedly secured some minor new Western territories, though these minor operations received no follow-up. Only ten years after his reign began, an expedition out of Alexandreia Eschate, resulted in the first Hellenic contact with China. Though the two peoples did maintain a profitable trade agreement, it led to a great mixing of cultures between both. The Baktrian Hellenes were mostly unaffected (though Chinese goods would eventually grace the shelves of Baktrian markets more frequently), but the contact supposedly inspired a great many principles within Chinese art that had been previously unseen in the mainstream. One particular notable instance suggested by Chinese records is the first Emperor Qin's terracota army, which might have been inspired by Hellenic figure design. This first expedition also led to the contacts that would eventually develop the Silk Road. With a comfortable frontier in the North and East, Euthydemos eventually met the Seleukid army under the direct command of King Antiochos III, approaching his South-Western border after successful campaigning in the area. During the ensuing conflict, Euthydemos managed to first repel an attack by the full Seleukid force, and to resist a two year siege; eventually managing to convince Antiochos of the value of an independent Hellenic kingdom in the far East. Recognizing the potential danger of the warlike nomads in the East, Antiochos decided to grant Euthydemos' kingdom it's independence so that they might serve as a buffer against further Eastern incursions in to the empire, and sealed the agreement by marrying one of his daughters to Euthydemos' son Demetrios.[PARAGRAPH:2]With the Seleukid threat to his kingdom neutralized, the Baktrians began focusing on conquest and the assimilation of several Western territories. Only a few years after Antiochos' departure, Euthydemos managed to absorb some of the old Northern provinces of Persia, and finally managed to subdue much of Parthia, thanks to their state of weakness after Antiochos' victories against them. Having secured much of Parthia, Euthydemos ruled for about a decade more before his death, of seemingly natural causes. During this time and the early years of his son's rule, the Baktrian borders remained static, save for a few varying losses and acquisitions in the West. His most significant undertaking, however, was an invasion of the Sungan kingdom in Northern India. This invasion was incredibly successful, with Demetrios securing almost all of the Sungan possessions, up to their capital - bringing the Hellenic rulers for the first time into power over lands heavily populated by an Indian majority. The influx of Hellenes into these possessions brought about a culture mingling between the Buddhists of India and the Hellenes, that would continue for five centuries after the rule of Hellenes ended in the region, influencing modern Buddhism in a variety of ways - and creating the Gandhara culture that would last a millenia. Examples of this Hellenic influence are more apparent then most would imagine, as the first statues of the Buddha himself were very likely executed by Hellenic artisans or commissioned by Hellenes. Before the Hellenes' arrival, most Buddhists in Northern India represented the Buddha with a small plethora of symbols; almost never giving him his human form in their design. It was also the Hellenes who first depicted him as standing or walking in their statuary design.[PARAGRAPH:2]By 175 BC, the conquest of India was completed, and most of Northern and North-Western India wasin Hellenic hands. Hellenic rule here was so successful, that it would outlast the actual Baktrian kingdom itself in the North, where even at this time internal feuding was once again disrupting the kingdom's growth. In Baktria itself, Antiochos III's cousin Eukratides had managed to secure the loyalty of all Demetrios' possessions before the path he followed to India. At the beginning of his rule, the Parthians reconquored the Baktrian's Western possessions, and Demetrios' brother Anthimachos I led an unsuccessful resistance to his rebellion, weakening him against the eventual reprisals of Demetrios, who was approaching once again from India. The two confronted each other, when Demetrios marched an army of 60,000 men, composed of Hellenes, Indians, and even some of his levies from inside Baktria itself. Despite numerical superiority, Eukratides managed to defeat Demetrios, forcing him to retreat into India - where his successors would rule for almost two centuries, promoting a further melding of cultures that would nearly complete the development of the Gandhara culture, and the creation of a Greaco-Hindu Buddhist pantheon focused around Apollo and the Buddha. Though Demetrius had been defeated by the Greaco-Baktrian army, his future successor Menandros I took his revenge for him, by recapturing most of Southern Baktria from Eukratides' successor, Eukratides II. After only a few years on the throne, Eukratides was also replaced through the political maneuvering of Platon Epiphanes around 166 BC, who ruled for twenty years of territorial loss and internal feuding. Upon Eukratides' death, Heliokles came into power, and ruled over the finally collapsing Graeco-Baktrian kingdom. The kingdom's final downfall came in 125 when he abandoned Baktria to the Yuezhi who had been eating up his territory for most of his rule, and moved his capital into the Hellenic territory of Northern India.

[TAB]The borders of present-day Bangladesh were established with the partition of Bengal and India in 1947, when the region became the eastern wing of the newly formed Pakistan. However, it was separated from the western wing by 1,600 kilometres (1,000 mi) across India. Political and linguistic discrimination as well as economic neglect led to popular agitations against West Pakistan, which led to the war for independence in 1971 and the establishment of Bangladesh. After independence the new state endured famines, natural disasters and widespread poverty, as well as political turmoil and military coups. The restoration of democracy in 1991 has been followed by relative calm and economic progress.[PARAGRAPH:2]Bangladesh is the seventh most populous country in the world and is among the most densely populated countries in the world with a high poverty rate. However, per-capita GDP has more than doubled since 1975, and the poverty rate has fallen by 20% since the early 1990s. The country is listed among the "Next Eleven" economies. Dhaka and other urban centers have been the driving force behind this growth.[PARAGRAPH:2]Remnants of civilization in the greater Bengal region date back four thousand years, when the region was settled by Dravidian, Tibeto-Burman, and Austro-Asiatic peoples. The exact origin of the word "Bangla" or "Bengal" is unknown, though it is believed to be derived from Bang, the Dravidian-speaking tribe that settled in the area around the year 1000 BC.[PARAGRAPH:2]The kingdom of Gangaridai was formed from at least the seventh century BC, which later united with Bihar under the Magadha, Nanda, Mauryan and Sunga Empires. Bengal was later part of the Gupta Empire and Harsha Empire from the third to the sixth centuries CE. Following its collapse, a dynamic Bengali named Shashanka founded an impressive yet short-lived kingdom. Shashanka is considered the first independent king in the history of Bangladesh. After a period of anarchy, the Buddhist Pala dynasty ruled the region for four hundred years, followed by a shorter reign of the Hindu Sena dynasty. Islam was introduced to Bengal in the twelfth century by Arab Muslim merchants and Sufi missionaries, and subsequent Muslim conquests helped spread Islam throughout the region. Bakhtiar Khilji, a Turkic general, defeated Lakshman Sen of the Sena dynasty and conquered large parts of Bengal in the year 1204. The region was ruled by dynasties of Sultans and land lords Bhuiyan for the next few hundred years. By the 16th century, the Mughal Empire controlled Bengal, and Dhaka became an important provincial centre of Mughal administration.[PARAGRAPH:2]European traders arrived late in the 15th century, and their influence grew until the British East India Company gained control of Bengal following the Battle of Plassey in 1757. The bloody rebellion of 1857, known as the Sepoy Mutiny, resulted in transfer of authority to the crown, with a British viceroy running the administration. During colonial rule, famine racked the Indian subcontinent many times, including the Great Bengal famine of 1943 that claimed 3 million lives.[PARAGRAPH:2]In January 11, 2007, following widespread violence, a caretaker government was appointed to administer the next general election. The country had suffered from extensive corruption, disorder and political violence. The new caretaker government has made it a priority to root out corruption from all levels of government. To this end, many notable politicians and officials, along with large numbers of lesser officials and party members, have been arrested on corruption charges. The caretaker government held a fair and free election on December 29, 2008. Awami League's Sheikh Hasina won the elections with a landslide victory and took oath of Prime Minister on 6 Jan 2009.

[TAB][TAB]The Batavii (or Batavi, Batavians) were a Germanic, or possibly Celtic tribe reported by Julius Caesar and Tacitus to have lived around the Rhine delta, in the area which is currently the Netherlands. This led to the Latin name of Batavia.[PARAGRAPH:2]They were mentioned by Julius Caesar in his commentary Gallic Wars, as living on an island formed by the Meuse River after it is joined by the Waal, 80 Roman miles from the mouth of the river. He said there were many other islands formed by branches of the Rhine, inhabited by savage and barbarous nations, some of whom were supposed to live on fish and the eggs of sea-fowl.[PARAGRAPH:2]Tacitus described the Batavi as the most brave of the tribes of the area, inhabiting not much territory on the Rhine but an island in it. They were formerly part of the Cattans[?] but moved after a feud to become part of the Roman Empire. He said they retained the honour of the ancient association with the Romans, not required to pay tribute or taxes and used by the Romans only for war. He named the Mattiacians[?] as a similar tribe under homage, but on the other (Germanic) side of the Rhine.[PARAGRAPH:2]Also the areas inhabited by the Batavians where never occupied by the Romans, they were allies. In 69 CE, a rebellion led by Julius Civilis arose, which was defeated by the Romans the following year.[PARAGRAPH:2]After the 3rd century CE, the Batavians are no longer mentioned, and they are assumed to have merged with the neighbouring Frisian and Frankish people.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Batavians became regarded as the eponymous ancestors of the Dutch people. The Netherlands were briefly known as the Batavian Republic.

[TAB]In the 1st century BC, the Romans, after defeating the local tribes, created the province of Gallia Belgica. A gradual immigration by Germanic Frankish tribes during the 5th century, brought the area under the rule of the Merovingian kings. A gradual shift of power during the 8th century led the kingdom of the Franks to evolve into the Carolingian Empire. The Treaty of Verdun in 843 divided the region into Middle and Western Francia and therefore into a set of more or less independent fiefdoms which during the Middle Ages were vassals either of the King of France or of the Roman Emperor. Many of these fiefdoms were united in the Burgundian Netherlands of the 14th and 15th centuries. Emperor Charles V extended the personal union of the Seventeen Provinces in the 1540s, making it far more than a personal union by the Pragmatic Sanction of 1549 and increased his influence over the Prince-Bishopric of Liège.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Eighty Years' War (15681648) divided the Low Countries into the northern United Provinces (Belgica Foederata in Latin, the "Federated Netherlands") and the Southern Netherlands (Belgica Regia, the "Royal Netherlands"). The latter were ruled successively by the Spanish and the Austrian Habsburgs and comprised most of modern Belgium. This was the theatre of most Franco-Spanish and Franco-Austrian wars during the 17th and 18th centuries. Following the campaigns of 1794 in the French Revolutionary Wars, the Low Countries  including territories that were never nominally under Habsburg rule, such as the Prince-Bishopric of Liège  were annexed by the French First Republic, ending Austrian rule in the region. The reunification of the Low Countries as the United Kingdom of the Netherlands occurred at the dissolution of the First French Empire in 1815. The 1830 Belgian Revolution led to the establishment of an independent, Catholic and neutral Belgium under a provisional government and a national congress. Since the installation of Leopold I as king in 1831, Belgium has been a constitutional monarchy and parliamentary democracy. Although the franchise was initially restricted, universal suffrage for men was introduced in 1893 (with plural voting until 1919) and for women in 1949. The main political parties of the 19th century were the Catholic Party and the Liberal Party, with the Belgian Labour Party emerging towards the end of the century. French was originally the single official language adopted by the nobility and the bourgeoisie. It progressively lost its overall importance as Dutch became recognized as well. This recognition became official in 1898 and in 1967 a Dutch version of the Constitution was legally accepted.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Berlin Conference of 1885 acceeded control of the Congo Free State to King Leopold II as his private possession. From around 1900 there was growing international concern for the extreme and savage treatment of the Congolese population under Leopold II, for whom the Congo was primarily a source of revenue from ivory and rubber production. In 1908 this outcry led the Belgian state to assume responsibility for the government of the colony, henceforth called the Belgian Congo.[PARAGRAPH:2]Germany invaded Belgium in 1914 as part of the Schlieffen Plan and much of the Western Front fighting of World War I occurred in western parts of the country. Belgium took over the German colonies of Ruanda-Urundi (modern day Rwanda and Burundi) during the war and they were mandated to Belgium in 1924 by the League of Nations. In the aftermath of the first World War, the Prussian districts of Eupen and Malmedy were annexed by Belgium 1925, thereby causing the presence of a German-speaking minority. The country was again invaded by Germany in 1940 during the Blitzkrieg offensive and occupied until its liberation in 1945 by the Allies. The Belgian Congo gained independence in 1960 during the Congo Crisis; Ruanda-Urundi followed two years later.[PARAGRAPH:2]After World War II, Belgium joined NATO as a founding member and formed the Benelux group of nations with the Netherlands and Luxembourg. Belgium became one of the six founding members of the European Coal and Steel Community in 1951 and of the European Atomic Energy Community and European Economic Community, established in 1957. The latter is now the European Union, for which Belgium hosts major administrations and institutions, including the European Commission, the Council of the European Union and the extraordinary and committee sessions of the European Parliament.

[TAB]The Benin Empire or Edo Empire was a large pre-colonial African state of modern Nigeria.[PARAGRAPH:2]According to one traditional account, the original people and founders of the Benin Empire, the Bini, were initially ruled by the Ogisos (Kings of the Sky). The city of Ibinu (later called Benin City) was founded in 1180 AD. About 36 known Ogiso are accounted for as rulers of the empire. [PARAGRAPH:2]Oranmiyan, the son of Ekaladerhan aka Oduduwa, agreed to go to Benin. He spent some years in Benin and came back to Ife after his wife gave birth to a son named Eweka. Eweka I became the first Oba of Benin. In 1440, Oba Ewuare (Ewuare the Great) came to power and turned the city-state into an empire. Around 1470, he named the new state Edo. The Oba had become the paramount power within the region. Oba Ewuare, the first Golden Age Oba, is credited with turning Benin City into a military fortress protected by moats and walls. It was from this bastion that he launched his military campaigns and began the expansion of the kingdom from the Edo-speaking heartlands. The lands of Idah, Owo, Akure all came under the central authority of the Edo Empire.[PARAGRAPH:2]At its maximum extent the empire is claimed by the Edos to have extended from Onitsha in the east, through the forested southwestern region of Nigeria and into the present-day nation of Ghana. The Ga peoples of Ghana trace their ancestry to the ancient Kingdom of Benin. The state developed an advanced artistic culture especially in its famous artifacts of bronze, iron and ivory. These include bronze wall plaques and life-sized bronze heads of the Obas of Benin. The most common artifact is based on Queen Idia, porpularly called the FESTAC mask. Benin grew increasingly rich during the 16th and 17th centuries on the slave trade with Europe; slaves from enemy states of the interior were sold, and carried to the Americas in Dutch and Portuguese ships. The Bight of Benin's shore soon came to be known as the "Slave Coast."[PARAGRAPH:2]The city and empire of Benin declined after 1700, but revived in the 19th century with the development of the trade in palm oil, enslaved captives, and textiles. To preserve Benin's independence, bit by bit the Oba banned the export of goods from Benin, until the trade was exclusively in palm oil.[PARAGRAPH:2]Benin resisted signing a protectorate treaty with Great Britain through most of the 1880s and 1890s. However, after the slaying of eight British representatives in Benin territory, a 'Punitive Expedition' was launched in 1897, in which a British force, under the command of Admiral Sir Harry Rawson, conquered and burned the city, destroying much of the countrys treasured art and dispersing nearly all that remained. The portrait figures, busts, and groups created in iron, carved ivory, and especially in brass (conventionally called the "Benin Bronzes") made in Benin are now displayed in museums around the world.

[TAB]Brazil is thought to have been inhabited for at least 10,000 years by semi-nomadic populations before the first Portuguese explorers, led by Pedro Álvares Cabral, disembarked in 1500. Over the next three centuries, it was resettled by the Portuguese and exploited mainly for brazilwood (Pau-Brasil) at first, and later for sugarcane (Cana-de-Açúcar) agriculture, coffee beans and gold mining. The colony's source of manpower was initially on enslaved Amerindians, and after 1550, mainly African slaves. In 1808, Queen Maria I of Portugal and her son and regent, the future João VI of Portugal, fleeing from Napoleon, relocated to Brazil with the royal family, nobles and government.[PARAGRAPH:2]Salvador is Brazil's third city in population and was the country's capital until 1763.Though they returned to Portugal in 1821, the interlude led to the opening of commercial ports to the United Kingdom - at the time isolated from most European ports by Napoleon - and to the elevation of Brazil to the status of a united kingdom with Portugal's Crown. Then prince regent Dom Pedro I (later Pedro IV of Portugal) declared independence on 7 September 1822, establishing the independent Empire of Brazil. As the crown remained in the hands of the house of Bragança, this was more the severance of the Portuguese empire in two, than an independence movement as seen elsewhere in the Americas.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Brazilian Empire was theoretically a democracy in the British style, although in practice, the emperor-premier-parliament balance of power more closely resembled the autocratic Austrian Empire. Slavery was abolished in 1888, through the "Golden Law", created by Princess Isabel, and intensive European immigration created the basis for industrialization. Pedro I was succeeded by his son, Pedro II - who in old age was caught by a political dispute between the Army and the Cabinet, a crisis arising from the Paraguay War. In order to avoid a civil war between Army and Navy, Pedro II renounced the throne on 15 November 1889, when a federal republic (officially, the Republic of the United States of Brazil) was established by Field Marshal Deodoro da Fonseca.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dom Pedro I declaring independence from Portugal on September 7, 1822. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Brazil attracted over 5 million European and Japanese immigrants. That period also saw Brazil industrialize, further colonize, and develop its interior. Brazilian democracy was replaced by dictatorships three times - 1930-1934 and 1937-1945 under Getúlio Vargas, and 1964-1985, under a succession of generals appointed by the military. Since 1985, Brazil has been internationally considered a democracy, specifically a presidential democracy, which was kept after a plebiscite in 1993 where voters had to choose between a presidential or parliamentary system, whilst also choosing if Brazil should reinstate its constitutional monarchy.[PARAGRAPH:2]A key feature of democracy in contemporary Brazil is the existence of a vibrant and participatory civil society. NGOs and citizen organizations are at the forefront of the struggle for human rights, gender equality and economic justice.

[TAB]The Bulgars arrived in the region from Central Asia in the 600s AD. They conquered the part of the Balkan Peninsula occupied by Slavs from the Byzantine Empire. In 681, Byzantium acknowledged the first Bulgarian empire, which lasted until 1081. Although they had ruled the country, the Bulgars adopted the language and traditions of the Slavs. During the Middle Ages, Bulgaria was a great military power. It frequently battled the Byzantine Empire and other neighbors and invaders. In 865 the Bulgarian ruler Tsar Boris I converted to Christianity. He set up the independent Bulgarian church and introduced the Cyrillic alphabet. This new language and church spread to other parts of eastern Europe, including Russia. During the reign of Boris's son, Simeon I, Bulgaria expanded both territorially and culturally. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Bulgaria declined in influence after Simeon's death. In 1018 the Byzantine emperor Basil II defeated the country and ended the first Bulgarian empire. Bulgaria remained part of the Byzantine Empire until 1186. In 1186, John Asen I and his brother Peter recovered Bulgaria's independence. Art and literature flourished under the reign of Tsar John Asen II, and many churches were founded. But in 1396, together with the remaining Balkan states, Bulgaria was conquered by the Ottoman Turks. [PARAGRAPH: 1] During the Ottoman rule of Bulgaria, the Bulgarian nobility diminished and the church had little power. Bulgarian farmers were made serfs to Turkish masters. The Bulgarians almost lost their cultural identity, for the ability to read and write had declined and few could recall their people's history. However, a Bulgarian national revival began in the 1800s. An independent Bulgarian church was reinstated in 1870. Some Bulgarians moved to the mountains and initiated a guerrilla campaign against Turkish rule. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Russia helped Bulgaria to earn political independence. Because many western European powers feared Russian expansion, only northern Bulgaria was freed. However, in 1885, the southern part of the country was reunited with Bulgaria. The European powers of the time did not believe that the Bulgarians were skilled enough to govern their own country in a democratic fashion. Instead, they proposed Bulgaria be ruled by a foreign monarch, first by Alexander Battenberg. However, Alexander gave up the throne in 1886, and it was passed on to Prince Ferdinand of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha. [PARAGRAPH: 1] In 1907, Prince Ferdinand assumed the title of Tsar and claimed the areas of old Bulgaria, particularly Macedonia. A Balkan alliance was created among Bulgaria, Serbia, Montenegro, and Greece. This alliance fought against the Turks in the First Balkan War in 1912. After bickering among themselves, Bulgaria was defeated by an alliance of Greece, Serbia, Romania, and Turkey in the Second Balkan War. This resulted in Bulgaria giving up its claims to Macedonia. [PARAGRAPH: 1] During World War I, Bulgaria allied itself with Germany and Austria-Hungary. Being on the losing side, it was forced to give up more land. Economic and political difficulties were caused with a flood of refugees from Macedonia and large war reparations. During World War II, Bulgaria allied itself with Germany once again. In 1944, Bulgaria held peace discussions with the Allies. Because these peace talks moved slowly, the Soviet Union declared war on Bulgaria and Bulgarian Communist leaders took power. In 1946, the monarchy was abolished and Bulgaria adopted a Communist government. During the years of Communist rule, political and cultural freedom was limited but industry was encouraged. In 1989, several Communist leaders were removed from power, leaving room for opposing parties to enter the government. The first elections under the new constitution were held in 1991.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le Bulgars est arrivé dans la région d'Asie centrale dans le 600s APRÈS JÉSUS CHRIST. Ils ont conquis la partie de la péninsule balkanique occupée par Slavs de l'empire bizantin. Dans 681, Byzance a reconnu le premier empire bulgare, qui a duré jusqu'en 1081. Bien qu'ils aient régné le pays, le Bulgars a adopté la langue et les traditions des Slaves. Pendant les âges moyens, la Bulgarie était une grande puissance militaire. Il a fréquemment lutté l'empire bizantin et d'autres voisins et envahisseurs. Dans 865 la règle bulgare Tsar Boris j'ai converti en christianisme. Il a établi l'église bulgare indépendante et a présenté l'alphabet cyrillien. Ces nouvelles langue et église se sont écartées à d'autres régions de l'Europe de l'Est, y compris la Russie. Pendant le règne du fils de Boris, Simeon I, Bulgarie a augmenté territorialement et culturelement. [PARAGRAPHE : 1] La Bulgarie a diminué dans l'influence après la mort de Simeon. Dans 1018 l'empereur bizantin Basil II a défait le pays et a fini le premier empire bulgare. La Bulgarie est restée une partie de l'empire bizantin jusqu'en 1186. En 1186, John Asen I et son frère Peter ont récupéré l'indépendance de la Bulgarie. L'art et la littérature se sont épanouis sous le règne de Tsar John Asen II, et beaucoup d'églises ont été fondées. Mais en 1396, ainsi que les états balkaniques restants, la Bulgarie a été conquise par les Turcs de tabouret. [PARAGRAPHE : 1] Pendant la règle de tabouret de la Bulgarie, la noblesse bulgare diminuée et l'église ont eu peu de puissance. Des fermiers bulgares ont été faits à des serfs aux maîtres turcs. Les Bulgares ont presque perdu leur identité culturelle, parce que la capacité de lire et écrire avait diminué et peu pourraient rappeler l'histoire de leurs personnes. Cependant, une renaissance nationale bulgare a commencé dans le 1800s. Une église bulgare indépendante a été rétablie en 1870. Quelques Bulgares se sont déplacés aux montagnes et lancent une campagne de guérillero contre la règle turque. [PARAGRAPHE : 1] La Russie a aidé la Bulgarie à gagner l'indépendance politique. Puisque beaucoup de puissances d'Europe occidentale ont craint l'expansion russe, seulement la Bulgarie nordique a été libérée. Cependant, en 1885, la partie méridionale du pays a été réunie à la Bulgarie. Les puissances européennes du temps n'ont pas cru que les Bulgares étaient assez habiles pour régir leur propre pays d'une mode démocratique. Au lieu de cela, ils ont proposé la Bulgarie soient régnés par un monarque étranger, d'abord par Alexandre Battenberg. Cependant, Alexandre a abandonné le trône en 1886, et il a été passé dessus à prince Ferdinand de Saxe-Cobourg-Gotha. [PARAGRAPHE : 1] En 1907, prince Ferdinand a assumé le titre de Tsar et a déclaré les régions de la vieille Bulgarie, en particulier Macédoine. Une alliance balkanique a été créée parmi la Bulgarie, la Serbie, le Montenegro, et la Grèce. Cette alliance a lutté contre les Turcs dans la première guerre balkanique en 1912. Après s'être querellé parmi eux-mêmes, la Bulgarie a été défaite par une alliance de la Grèce, de la Serbie, de la Roumanie, et de la Turquie dans la deuxième guerre balkanique. Ceci a eu comme conséquence la Bulgarie abandonnant ses réclamations à Macédoine. [PARAGRAPHE : 1] Pendant la Première Guerre Mondiale, la Bulgarie s'est alliée avec l'Allemagne et l'Autriche-Hongrie. Étant du côté perdant, il a été forcé d'abandonner plus de terre. Des difficultés économiques et politiques ont été causées avec une pléthore de réfugiés de Macédoine et de grandes réparations de guerre. Pendant la deuxième guerre mondiale, la Bulgarie s'est alliée de nouveau avec l'Allemagne. En 1944, la Bulgarie a tenu des discussions de paix avec les alliés. Puisque ces entretiens de paix se sont déplacés lentement, l'Union Soviétique a déclaré la guerre sur la Bulgarie et les chefs communistes bulgares ont pris la puissance. En 1946, la monarchie a été supprimée et la Bulgarie a adopté un gouvernement communiste. Pendant les années de la règle communiste, la liberté politique et culturelle était limitée mais l'industrie a été encouragée. En 1989, plusieurs chefs communistes ont été enlevés de la puissance, partant de la pièce pour que des parties d'opposition écrivent le gouvernement. Les premières élections sous la nouvelle constitution ont été tenues en 1991.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Das Bulgars kam in der Region von zentralem Asien im 600s V. CHR. an. Sie eroberten das Teil der Balkan Halbinsel, die von Slavs vom byzantinischen Reich besetzt wurde. In 681 bestätigte Byzanz das erste bulgarische Reich, das bis 1081 dauerte. Obgleich sie das Land angeordnet hatten, nahm das Bulgars die Sprache und die Traditionen der Slavs an. Während des mittleren Alters war Bulgarien eine große militärische Energie. Es kämpfte häufig das byzantinische Reich und andere Nachbarn und Eindringlinge. In 865 die bulgarische Lehre Tsar Boris wandelte ich in Christentum um. Er stellte die unabhängige bulgarische Kirche auf und stellte das kyrillische Alphabet vor. Diese neue Sprache und Kirche verbreiteten zu anderen Teilen von Osteuropa, einschließlich Rußland. Während der Herrschaft von Sohn Boriss, erweiterte Simeon I, Bulgarien territorial und kulturell. [PUNKT: 1] Bulgarien sank im Einfluß nach Tod Simeons. In 1018 besiegte der byzantinische Kaiser Basilikum II das Land und beendete das erste bulgarische Reich. Bulgarien blieb Teil des byzantinischen Reiches bis 1186. 1186 gewannen John Asen I und sein Bruder Peter Unabhängigkeit Bulgariens zurück. Kunst und Literatur blühten unter der Herrschaft von Tsar John Asen II, und viele Kirchen wurden gegründet. Aber 1396, zusammen mit den restlichen Balkan Zuständen, wurde Bulgarien von den Ottoman-Türken erobert. [PUNKT: 1] Während der Ottomanrichtlinie von Bulgarien, hatten der bulgarische verminderte Adel und die Kirche wenig Energie. Bulgarische Landwirte wurden Sklaven zu den türkischen Meistern gebildet. Die Bulgaren verloren fast ihre kulturelle Identität, denn die Fähigkeit zu lesen und zu schreiben war gesunken und wenige konnten Geschichte ihrer Leute zurückrufen. Jedoch fing eine bulgarische nationale Wiederbelebung im 1800s an. Eine unabhängige bulgarische Kirche wurde 1870 wiedereingesetzt. Einige Bulgaren zogen auf die Berge um und leiten eine Bandenkämpferkampagne gegen türkische Richtlinie ein. [PUNKT: 1] Rußland half Bulgarien, politische Unabhängigkeit zu erwerben. Weil viele westeuropäische Energien russische Expansion fürchteten, nur Nordbulgarien freigegeben wurde. Jedoch 1885, wurde das südliche Teil des Landes mit Bulgarien gewiedervereinigt. Die europäischen Energien der Zeit glaubten nicht, daß die Bulgaren genug erfahren waren, ihr eigenes Land auf eine demokratische Art und Weise zu regeln. Stattdessen schlugen sie Bulgarien werden angeordnet von einem fremden Monarchen vor, zuerst durch Alexander Battenberg. Jedoch gab Alexander oben den Thron 1886, und dem Prinzen Ferdinand von Saxe-Kammgarn-stoff-Gotha er wurde an geführt. [PUNKT: 1] 1907, nahm Prinz Ferdinand den Titel Tsar an und erklärte die Bereiche von altem Bulgarien, besonders Mazedonien. Ein Balkan Bündnis wurde unter Bulgarien, Serbien, Montenegro und Griechenland verursacht. Dieses Bündnis kämpfte gegen die Türken im ersten Balkankrieg 1912. Nachdem man unter selbst bickering, wurde Bulgarien durch ein Bündnis von Griechenland, von Serbien, von Rumänien und von Türkei im zweiten Balkankrieg besiegt. Dieses ergab Bulgarien, das Mazedonien herauf seine Ansprüche gibt. [PUNKT: 1] Während des Ersten Weltkrieges verband sich Bulgarien mit Deutschland und Österreich-Ungarn. Seiend auf der Schlussen Seite, wurde es gezwungen, um mehr Land oben zu geben. Ökonomische und politische Schwierigkeiten wurden mit einer Flut der Flüchtlinge von Mazedonien und von den großen Kriegreparationen verursacht. Während des Zweiten Weltkrieges verband sich Bulgarien mit Deutschland noch einmal. 1944 hielt Bulgarien Friedensdiskussionen mit den Verbündeten. Weil diese Friedensgespräche langsam bewogen, erklärte die Sowjetunion Krieg auf Bulgarien und bulgarische kommunistische Führer nahmen Energie. 1946 wurde die Monarchie abgeschafft und Bulgarien nahm eine kommunistische Regierung an. Während der Jahre der kommunistischen Richtlinie, war politische und kulturelle Freiheit begrenzt, aber Industrie wurde angeregt. 1989 wurden einige kommunistische Führer von der Energie entfernt und verließen Raum, damit entgegensetzende Parteien die Regierung eintragen. Die ersten Wahlen unter der neuen Beschaffenheit wurden 1991 gehalten.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Il Bulgars è arrivato nella regione dall'Asia centrale nell'ANNUNCIO 600s. Hanno conquistato la parte della penisola Balkan occupata da Slavs dall'impero Byzantine. In 681, Byzantium ha riconosciuto il primo impero bulgaro, che ha durato fino al 1081. Anche se avevano regolato il paese, il Bulgars ha adottato la lingua e le tradizioni degli Slavs. Durante Medio Evo, la Bulgaria era un'alimentazione militare grande. Ha combattuto frequentemente l'impero Byzantine ed altri vicini ed invaders. In 865 il righello bulgaro Tsar Boris mi sono convertito in Christianity. Ha installato la chiesa bulgara indipendente ed ha introdotto l'alfabeto cirillico. Queste nuove lingua e chiesa si sono sparse ad altre zone dell'Europa Orientale, compreso la Russia. Durante il regno del figlio del Boris, Simeon I, Bulgaria si è espanso sia territoriale che culturalmente. [PARAGRAFO: 1] La Bulgaria ha declinato nell'influenza dopo la morte del Simeon. In 1018 il basilico Byzantine dell'imperatore II ha sconfitto il paese ed ha concluso il primo impero bulgaro. La Bulgaria è rimasto parte dell'impero Byzantine fino al 1186. In 1186, John Asen I ed il suo fratello Peter hanno recuperato l'indipendenza della Bulgaria. L'arte e la letteratura sono fiorito sotto il regno di Tsar John Asen II e molte chiese sono state fondate. Ma in 1396, insieme al Balcani restante dichiara, la Bulgaria è stato conquistato dai Turchi del Ottoman. [PARAGRAFO: 1] Durante la regola del Ottoman della Bulgaria, il nobility bulgaro diminuito e la chiesa hanno avuti poca alimentazione. I coltivatori bulgari sono stati resi a servi ai padroni turchi. I bulgari quasi hanno perso la loro identità culturale, dato che la capacità di leggere e scrivere aveva declinato e poche potrebbero ricordare la storia della loro gente. Tuttavia, una rinascita nazionale bulgara ha cominciato nel 1800s. Una chiesa bulgara indipendente è stata reintegrata in 1870. Alcuni bulgari si sono mossi verso le montagne ed iniziano una campagna del guerrigliero contro la regola turca. [PARAGRAFO: 1] La Russia ha aiutato la Bulgaria a guadagnare l'indipendenza politica. Poiché molte alimentazioni d'Europa occidentale hanno temuto l'espansione russa, solo la Bulgaria del Nord è stata liberata. Tuttavia, in 1885, la parte del sud del paese reunited con la Bulgaria. Le alimentazioni europee del tempo non hanno creduto che i bulgari fossero abbastanza esperti governare il loro proprio paese ad un modo democratico. Invece, hanno proposto la Bulgaria sono regolati da un monarca straniero, in primo luogo da Alexander Battenberg. Tuttavia, Alexander ha dato in su il throne in 1886 ed è stato passato sopra al principe Ferdinand di Saxe-Coburg-Gotha. [PARAGRAFO: 1] In 1907, il principe Ferdinand ha ammesso il titolo di Tsar ed ha dichiarato le regioni di vecchia Bulgaria, specialmente Macedonia. Un'alleanza Balkan è stata generata fra la Bulgaria, la Serbia, Montenegro e la Grecia. Questa alleanza ha combattuto contro i Turchi nella prima guerra Balkan in 1912. Dopo bickering fra se stesso, la Bulgaria è stata sconfitta da un'alleanza della Grecia, della Serbia, della Romania e di Turchia nella seconda guerra Balkan. Ciò ha provocato in Bulgaria che dà sui relativi reclami a Macedonia. [PARAGRAFO: 1] Durante la guerra mondiale I, la Bulgaria si è alleata con la Germania e l'Austria-Ungheria. Essendo dal lato perdente, è stato costretto per dare in su più terra. Le difficoltà economiche e politiche sono state causate con una pletora di rifugiati da Macedonia e dai grandi reparations di guerra. Durante la seconda guerra mondiale, la Bulgaria si è alleata ancora una volta con la Germania. In 1944, la Bulgaria ha avuto le discussioni di pace con gli alleati. Poiché questi colloqui di pace si sono mossi lentamente, l'Unione Sovietica ha dichiarato la guerra con Bulgaria ed i capi comunisti bulgari hanno preso l'alimentazione. In 1946, il monarchy si è abolito e la Bulgaria ha adottato un governo comunista. Durante gli anni della regola comunista, la libertà politica e culturale era limitata ma l'industria è stata consigliata a. In 1989, parecchi capi comunisti sono stati rimossi da alimentazione, lasciante la stanza affinchè i partiti avversari entrino nel governo. Le prime elezioni a norma di nuova costituzione sono state tenute in 1991.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El Bulgars llegó en la región de Asia central en el ANUNCIO 600s. Conquistaron la parte de la península balcánica ocupada por slavs del imperio Byzantine. En 681, Byzantium reconoció el primer imperio búlgaro, que duró hasta 1081. Aunque habían gobernado el país, el Bulgars adoptó la lengua y las tradiciones de los eslavos. Durante las edades medias, Bulgaria era una gran energía militar. Luchó con frecuencia el imperio Byzantine y otros vecinos e invasores. En 865 la regla búlgara Tsar Boris convertí al cristianismo. Él instaló la iglesia búlgara independiente e introdujo el alfabeto cirílico. Esta lengua e iglesia nuevas se separaron a otras partes de Europa Oriental, incluyendo Rusia. Durante el reinado del hijo de Boris, Simeon I, Bulgaria se amplió territorial y cultural. [PÁRRAFO: 1] Bulgaria declinó en influencia después de la muerte de Simeon. En 1018 la albahaca Byzantine del emperador II derrotó el país y terminó el primer imperio búlgaro. Bulgaria seguía siendo parte del imperio Byzantine hasta 1186. En 1186, Juan Asen I y su hermano Peter recuperaron la independencia de Bulgaria. El arte y la literatura prosperaron bajo reinado de Tsar Juan Asen II, y muchas iglesias fueron fundadas. Pero en 1396, junto con los estados balcánicos restantes, Bulgaria fue conquistada por los turcos del otomano. [PÁRRAFO: 1] Durante la regla del otomano de Bulgaria, la nobleza búlgara disminuida y la iglesia tenían poca energía. Hicieron los granjeros búlgaros los siervos a los amos turcos. Los búlgaros casi perdieron su identidad cultural, porque la capacidad de leer y de escribir había declinado y poca podría recordar la historia de su gente. Sin embargo, un renacimiento nacional búlgaro comenzó en el 1800s. Una iglesia búlgara independiente fue reinstalada en 1870. Algunos búlgaros se trasladaron a las montañas e iniciaron una campaña del guerrilla contra regla turca. [PÁRRAFO: 1] Rusia ayudó a Bulgaria a ganar independencia política. Porque muchas energías de Europa occidental temieron la extensión rusa, sólo Bulgaria norteña fue liberada. Sin embargo, en 1885, la parte meridional del país fue juntada con Bulgaria. Las energías europeas del tiempo no creyeron que los búlgaros eran bastante expertos gobernar su propio país en una manera democrática. En lugar, propusieron Bulgaria sean gobernados por un monarca extranjero, primero por Alexander Battenberg. Sin embargo, Alexander dio para arriba el trono en 1886, y fue pasado encendido a príncipe Ferdinand de Saxe-Coburg-Gotha. [PÁRRAFO: 1] En 1907, príncipe Ferdinand asumió el título de Tsar y declaró las áreas de vieja Bulgaria, particularmente Macedonia. Una alianza balcánica fue creada entre Bulgaria, Serbia, Montenegro, y Grecia. Esta alianza luchó contra los turcos en la primera guerra balcánica en 1912. Después de discutir entre sí mismos, Bulgaria fue derrotada por una alianza de Grecia, de Serbia, de Rumania, y de Turquía en la segunda guerra balcánica. Esto dio lugar a Bulgaria que daba encima de sus demandas a Macedonia. [PÁRRAFO: 1] Durante Primera Guerra Mundial, Bulgaria se alió con Alemania y Austria-Hungría. Estando en el lado perdidoso, fue forzado para dar para arriba más tierra. Las dificultades económicas y políticas fueron causadas con una inundación de refugiados de Macedonia y de reparaciones grandes de la guerra. Durante la Segunda Guerra Mundial, Bulgaria se alió con Alemania de nuevo. En 1944, Bulgaria llevó a cabo discusiones de la paz con los aliados. Porque estas negociaciones de la paz se movieron lentamente, la Unión Soviética declaró guerra en Bulgaria y los líderes comunistas búlgaros tomaron energía. En 1946, la monarquía fue suprimida y Bulgaria adoptó un gobierno comunista. Durante los años de la regla comunista, la libertad política y cultural era limitada pero la industria fue animada. En 1989, quitaron a varios líderes comunistas de la energía, saliendo del sitio para que los partidos de oposición incorporen el gobierno. Las primeras elecciones bajo nueva constitución fueron celebradas en 1991.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Humans lived in the region that is now Burma as early as 11,000 years ago, but the first identifiable civilisation is that of the Pyu although both Burman and Mon tradition claim that the fabled Suvarnabhumi mentioned in ancient Pali and Sanskrit texts was a Mon kingdom centred on Thaton in present day Mon state. Artifacts from the excavated site of Nyaunggan help to reconstruct Bronze Age life in Burma and the more recent archaeological evidence at Samon Valley south of Mandalay suggests rice growing settlements between about 500 BC and AD 200 which traded with Qin and Han dynasty China.[PARAGRAPH:2]The 6th century Mon kingdom of Dvaravati in the lower Chao Phraya valley in present day Thailand extended its frontiers to the Tenasserim Yoma (mountains). With subjugation by the Khmer Empire from Angkor in the 11th century the Mon shifted further west deeper into present day Burma. Oral tradition suggests that they had contact with Buddhism via seafaring as early as the 3rd century BC and had received an envoy of monks from Ashoka in the 2nd century BC. The Mons adopted Indian culture together with Theravada Buddhism and are thought to have founded kingdoms in Lower Burma including Thaton in the 6th or 7th century and Bago (Pegu) in 825 with the kingdom of Raman'n'adesa (or Ramanna which is believed to be Thaton) referenced by Arab geographers in 844-8. The lack of archaeological evidence for this may in part be due to the focus of excavation work predominantly being in Upper Burma.[PARAGRAPH:2]After the fall of Pagan, the Mongols left in the searing Irrawaddy valley but the Pagan Kingdom was irreparably broken up into several small kingdoms. By the early 15th century, the country became organized along four major power centers: Upper Burma, Lower Burma, Shan States and Arakan. Many of the power centers were themselves made up of (often loosely held) minor kingdoms or princely states. This era was marked by a series of wars and switching alliances. Smaller kingdoms played a precarious game of paying allegiance to more powerful states, sometimes simultaneously.[PARAGRAPH:2]Britain made Burma a province of India in 1886 with the capital at Rangoon. Traditional Burmese society was drastically altered by the demise of the monarchy and the separation of religion and state. Though war officially ended after only a couple of weeks, resistance continued in northern Burma until 1890. The economic nature of society also changed dramatically. After the opening of the Suez Canal, the demand for Burmese rice grew and vast tracts of land were opened up for cultivation. However, in order to prepare the new land for cultivation, farmers were forced to borrow money from Indian moneylenders called chettiars at high interest rates and were often foreclosed on and evicted losing land and livestock. Most of the jobs also went to indentured Indian labourers, and whole villages became outlawed as they resorted to 'dacoity' (armed robbery).[PARAGRAPH:2]The first years of Burmese independence were marked by successive insurgencies by the Red Flag Communists led by Thakin Soe, the White Flag Communists led by Thakin Than Tun, the Yèbaw Hpyu (White-band PVO) led by Bo La Yaung, a member of the Thirty Comrades, army rebels calling themselves the Revolutionary Burma Army (RBA) led by Communist officers Bo Zeya, Bo Yan Aung and Bo Yè Htut. Remote areas of Northern Burma were for many years controlled by an army of Kuomintang (KMT) forces after the Communist victory in China in 1949. Burma accepted foreign assistance in rebuilding the country in these early years, but continued American support for the Chinese Nationalist military presence in Burma finally resulted in the country rejecting most foreign aid, refusing to join the South-East Asia Treaty Organization (SEATO) and supporting the Bandung Conference of 1955. Burma generally strove to be impartial in world affairs and was one of the first countries in the world to recognize Israel and the People's Republic of China.[PARAGRAPH:2]The military government announced a change of name for the country in English from Burma to Myanmar in 1989. It also continued the economic reforms started by the old regime and called for a Constituent Assembly to revise the 1974 Constitution. This led to multiparty elections in May 1990 in which the National League for Democracy (NLD) won a landslide victory over the National Unity Party (NUP, the successor to the BSPP) and about a dozen smaller parties. The military, however, would not let the assembly convene, and continued to hold the two leaders of the NLD, U Tin U and Aung San Suu Kyi, daughter of Aung San, under house arrest imposed on them the previous year. Burma came under increasing international pressure to convene the elected assembly, particularly after Aung San Suu Kyi was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1991, and also faced economic sanctions. In April 1992 the military replaced Saw Maung with General Than Shwe.

[TAB]Various groups of prehistoric peoples inhabited what is now Canada. Europeans first arrived when the Vikings briefly settled in Canada around 1000 AD. In the late 1400s and early 1500s, France and England began to send explorers to Canada. French explorer Samuel de Champlain arrived in 1603 and set up the first enduring European settlements at Port Royal in 1605 and Quebec City in 1608. These new colonies would come to be known as New France. Various fur traders came to Canada to participate in the trade with the Native Americans. When tensions grew, the French and Iroquois Wars broke out over control of the fur trade. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Once the English began settling in Canada and the Thirteen Colonies, several wars broke out resulting in much of the French lands in Canada to be ceded to England. Canadian borders expanded, and it saw a high number of Irish and British immigrants in the early 1800s. The timber industry would also surpass the fur trade in importance during this time. The desire for Responsible Government resulted after the Rebellions of 1837. The Act of Union in 1840 united all the Canadian lands into a United Province of Canada. French and English Canadians worked together in the Assembly to restore French rights, which had long been overlooked after Britain's domination in the 1800s. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Canada expanded even more in the mid-1800s through a series of westward expeditions. The move toward uniting Upper and Lower Canada into one country increased during this time of increased English Canadian nationalism. Following several constitutional conferences, the British North America Act brought about a Confederation creating one country under the name Canada with four provinces: Ontario, Quebec, Nova Scotia, and New Brunswick. In time, other provinces joined the Confederation. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Prime Minster John A. Macdonald's Conservative Party set up a National Policy of tariffs to protect emerging Canadian manufacturing industries. The open the West, the government sponsored construction of three transcontinental railways. Additionally, the government opened the prairies settlements and established its dominion over the territory. After the Klondike Gold Rush in 1898, the government decided to create the Yukon Territory as a separate territory. In 1905, Alberta and Saskatchewan became provinces as more immigrants settled in the prairies. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Canada entered World War I in 1914, sending volunteers to the Western Front. In 1919, Canada joined the League of Nations independently of Britain. In 1931, the Statute of Westminster asserted Canada's independence. The Great Depression of 1929 brought economic hardship to Canada. Canada declared war on Germany independently during World War II under Prime Minister William Lyon Mackenzie King, three days after Britain. The Canadian economy boomed as industry manufactured military material for itself, Britain, China and the Soviet Union. Canada finished the war with one of the largest armed forces in the world [PARAGRAPH: 1] Quebec experienced deep social and economic changes during the Quiet Revolution of the 1960s. Under successive Liberal governments of Lester B. Pearson and Pierre Trudeau, a new Canadian identity emerged. Canada adopted its current Maple Leaf Flag in 1965. Various acts combating cultural discrimination were passed in the 1960s and 1970s as waves of non-European immigration changed the face of the country. Social democratic programs such as Universal Healthcare, the Canada Pension Plan, and Canada Student Loans were passed during this time. In the 1980s, the Canadian government pushed toward free trade and closer relations with the United States. Because of these moves and others toward America, many Canadians worry about their cultural difference from the United States. However, Canadians take special pride in their system of universal healthcare and their commitment to multiculturalism.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les divers groupes de peuples préhistoriques ont habité ce qui est maintenant le Canada. Européens sont arrivés la première fois quand Vikings brièvement s'est établi au Canada autour de 1000 APRÈS JÉSUS CHRIST. Vers la fin de 1400s et de 1500s tôt, la France et l'Angleterre ont commencé à envoyer des explorateurs au Canada. L'explorateur français Samuel de Champlain est arrivé en 1603 et a établi les premiers règlements européens durables à la ville gauche royale en 1605 et du Québec en 1608. Ces nouvelles colonies viendraient pour être connues en tant que nouvelle France. Les divers commerçants de fourrure sont venus au Canada pour participer au commerce avec les Américains indigènes. Quand les tensions se sont développées, les guerres de Français et d'Iroquois ont éclaté au-dessus de la commande du commerce de fourrure. [PARAGRAPH : 1] Par le passé l'anglais a commencé à s'établir au Canada et les treize colonies, plusieurs guerres ont éclaté ayant pour résultat une grande partie des terres françaises au Canada à céder en Angleterre. Les frontières canadiennes ont augmenté, et il a vu un nombre élevé d'immigrés irlandais et britanniques dans le 1800s tôt. L'industrie de bois de construction surpasserait également le commerce de fourrure dans l'importance pendant ce temps. Le désir pour le gouvernement responsable a résulté après les rébellions de 1837. La Loi de l'union dans 1840 a uni toutes terres de Canadien dans une province unie du Canada. Les Canadiens français et anglais ont travaillé ensemble dans l'Assemblée pour reconstituer les droites françaises, qui avaient été longtemps négligées après la domination de la Grande-Bretagne dans le 1800s. [PARAGRAPH : 1] Le Canada augmenté encore plus dans le mid-1800s par une série d'expéditions à l'ouest. Le mouvement vers unir le Canada supérieur et inférieur dans un pays a augmenté pendant cette période du nationalisme canadien anglais accru. Après plusieurs conférences constitutionnelles, l'acte des Anglais Amérique du Nord a provoqué une confédération créant un pays sous le nom du Canada avec quatre provinces : Ontario, le Québec, Nouvelle-Écosse, et le Nouveau Brunswick. À temps, d'autres provinces ont joint la confédération. [PARAGRAPH : 1] Minster principal John A. La partie conservatrice de Macdonald a établi une politique nationale des tarifs pour protéger des industries canadiennes naissantes. L'ouvert l'ouest, la construction commanditée par le gouvernement de trois chemins de fer transcontinentaux. En plus, le gouvernement a ouvert les règlements de prairies et a établi son dominion au-dessus du territoire. Après que les précipitations d'or de Klondike en 1898, le gouvernement aient décidé de créer le territoire de Yukon comme territoire séparé. En 1905, Alberta et Saskatchewan sont devenus des provinces en tant que plus d'immigrés arrangés dans les prairies. [PARAGRAPH : 1] Le Canada a écrit la Première Guerre Mondiale en 1914, envoyant offre à l'avant occidental. En 1919, le Canada a adhéré à la ligue des nations indépendamment de la Grande-Bretagne. En 1931, le statut de Westminster a affirmé l'indépendance du Canada. La grande dépression de 1929 a apporté des difficultés économiques au Canada. Le Canada a déclaré la guerre sur l'Allemagne indépendamment pendant la deuxième guerre mondiale sous le roi de William Lyon Mackenzie de premier ministre, trois jours après la Grande-Bretagne. L'économie canadienne a grondé en tant que matériel militaire construit par industrie pour elle-même, la Grande-Bretagne, la Chine et l'Union Soviétique.
