Diverse le guerre con i faraoni per il controllo della Siria, ha causato il Mitanni e egiziani a formare un'alleanza. Durante il regno Shaushtatar, Mitanni è cresciuto al suo zenit. Dopo la morte di Shuttarna, Mitanni è stato devastato da una guerra di successione. Dopo un re infine rivendicato il trono, Mitanni era stata notevolmente indebolita. Al tempo stesso, sia la ittita e assira maggiore potenza, portando ad una maggiore thread Mitanni. Nella capitale Washukanni una nuova lotta di potere scoppiata. Alla fine, dopo le guerre con gli Ittiti e Assiri, Mitanni era notevolmente indebolita e fu infine annessa dal re assiro Shalmaneser nel 13 ° secolo aC. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Un altro Hurrian regno ha beneficiato anche la scomparsa di potenza babilonese nel XVI secolo aC. Il Hurrians ora abitato la regione nord-est del fiume Tigri. Il regno che è stato Arrapha qui emerse. Scavi presso uno dei Arrapha città capoluogo, Nuzi, dimostrato di essere un importante fonte di informazioni circa la Hurrians. Infine, questo regno fu distrutta dal assiri e il XIV secolo aC. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Con il tredicesimo secolo aC, tutti gli Stati Hurrian era stato sconfitto da altri popoli. Il cuore della Hurrian terre, il Khabur River Valley, divenne provincia assira. Hurrian la popolazione in Siria sembra aver dato loro la lingua in favore di accado assira dialetto, o, più probabilmente, l'aramaico.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB] Al igual que muchos aspectos de la cultura Hurrita, sus orígenes son aún un misterio. En 2400 aC, los hurritas puede haber ampliado de las faldas de la cordillera del Cáucaso al norte de Mesopotamia. El valle del río Jabur se convirtió en el corazón de los hurritas tierras para un milenio. El primer reino conocido Hurrita se centra en la ciudad de Urkesh durante el tercer milenio antes de Cristo. El final del Imperio acadio permitido a los hurritas a hacerse con el control de la zona. Ahora los hurritas podrían beneficiarse de las ricas culturas anteriores que viven allí y organizar su propia ciudad-estado avanzado. Urkesh había algunos poderosos vecinos. Sus vecinos incluyen los poderosos Amorite reino de Mari y la capital de un reino llamado Antiguo asirio-Shubat Enlil fue fundada a cierta distancia de Urkesh hurritas en otro asentamiento en el valle del río Jabur. [PARAGRAPH: 1] El hurritas también emigraron al oeste, y por el 1725 aC sus restos se encuentran en el norte de Siria. Los primeros reinos hurritas, como Kizzuwatna, florecieron durante este tiempo. Sin embargo, muchos de ellos se encuentran moderada por los hititas, los cuales son influenciados por la cultura Hurrita durante siglos. La destrucción del reino de Babilonia por los hititas permitido una poderosa dinastía hurritas aumentando. Un legendario rey, Kirta, fundó el reino de Mitanni alrededor de 1500 aC. Mitanni gradualmente creció de la región en todo el Valle del Khabur y se convirtió en el reino más poderoso de Oriente Próximo en el 1400 y 1300 antes de Cristo. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Rey Barattarna de Mitanni amplió el reino Mitanni mucho, y de la nación creció aún más fuerte bajo el reinado de Shaushtatar. Hurrita otros reinos, como Kizzuwatna y Ishuwa, demostrado poderosos aliados contra los hititas hostil. Varias guerras con los faraones por el control de Siria causó la Mitanni y egipcios para formar una alianza. Durante el reinado de Shaushtatar, Mitanni creció a su cenit. Después de la muerte de Shuttarna, Mitanni fue asolado por una guerra de sucesión. Después de un rey alegó finalmente el trono, Mitanni se había debilitado considerablemente. En este mismo tiempo, tanto el hitita y asiria aumento de potencia, con lo que un mayor flujo de Mitanni. En la capital Washukanni una nueva lucha de poder estalló. Eventualmente, después de las guerras con los hititas y los asirios, Mitanni se debilitó mucho y fue anexada por el rey asirio Shalmaneser en el siglo 13 antes de Cristo. [PARAGRAPH: 1] Otro hurritas reino también se benefició de la desaparición del poder de Babilonia en el siglo XVI antes de Cristo. El hurritas ahora habitado la región noreste del río Tigris. El reino que surgió aquí fue Arrapha. Las excavaciones en uno de Arrapha jefe de las ciudades, Nuzi, demostró ser una importante fuente de información acerca de los hurritas. Eventualmente, este reino fue destruido por los asirios en el siglo XIV aC. [PARAGRAPH: 1] En el siglo XIII antes de Cristo, todos los estados hurritas habían sido vencidos por otros pueblos. El corazón de los hurritas tierras, el valle del río Jabur, se convirtió en una provincia asiria. La población hurritas en Siria parece haber renunciado a su idioma en favor de los asirios dialecto acadio, o, más probable, arameo.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The area now comprising the archipelago of Indonesia, specifically Java, was inhabited by Homo erectus approximately 500,000 years ago, while the island of Flores was home to a newly discovered species of hominid, Homo floresiensis until approximately 10,000 years ago. The date of the earliest arrival of Homo Sapiens into the area was between 40,000 and 100,000 years ago. The earliest historical mention of the area was of the Jawa Dwipa Hindu kingdom in Java and Sumatra around 200 BC by Indian scholars, and various archeological sites show the influence of the Hindu religion in the area from the first century AD to the fifth century AD.[PARAGRAPH:2]Under the influences of Hinduism and Buddhism, several kingdoms formed on the islands of Sumatra and Java from the 7th to 14th century. The arrival of Arabs trading in spices later brought Islam, which became the dominant religion in many parts of the archipelago after the collapse of Hindu and Buddhist kingdoms. When the Portuguese came in early 16th century, they found a multitude of small states, vulnerable to the Portuguese, and later other Europeans wanting to dominate the spice trade.[PARAGRAPH:2]During World War II, with the Netherlands under German occupation, Japan began a five-prong campaign in December 1941 towards Java and the vital fuel supplies of the Dutch East Indies. Though Japan captured Java by March 1942,it initially could not find any national leader willing to collaborate with the Japanese government against the Dutch. In 1945, with the war drawing to a close, Indonesian leader Sukarno was made aware of an opportunity to declare independence. In response to lobbying, Japan agreed to allow Sukarno to establish a committee to plan for independence. However, Sukarno and Mohammad Hatta declared independence unilaterally on 17 August, soon after the Japanese lost the war. Following the defeat of Japan in the World War, the Netherlands' Army, at first backed by the British, attempted to reoccupy their former East Indies colonies. Indonesia's war for independence lasted from 1945 until 27 December 1949 when, under heavy international pressure, especially from the United States, which threatened to cut off Marshall Plan funds, the Netherlands acknowledged the independence of Indonesia as a Federation of autonomous states. This federation soon became a republic with Sukarno as president and Hatta as vice president. It was not until 16 August 2005 that the Dutch government recognized 1945 as the country's year of independence and expressed regrets over the Indonesian deaths caused by the Netherlands' Army.[PARAGRAPH:2]The 1950s and 1960s saw Sukarno's government aligned first with the emerging non-aligned movement and later with the socialist bloc. The 1960s saw Indonesia in a military confrontation against neighbouring Malaysia, and increasing frustration over domestic economic difficulties. Army general Suharto became president in 1967 on the pretext of securing the country against an alleged communist coup attempt against a weakening Sukarno, whose tilt leftward had alarmed both the military and Western powers. In the aftermath of Suharto's rise, hundreds of thousands of people were killed or imprisoned by the military and religious groups in a backlash against alleged communist supporters. Suharto's administration is commonly called the New Order era. Suharto invited major foreign investment, which produced substantial, if uneven, economic growth. However, Suharto enriched himself and his family through widespread corruption and was forced to step down amid massive popular demonstrations and a faltering economy by the Indonesian Revolution of 1998.[PARAGRAPH:2]President BJ Habibie promised a multiparty, free, democratic election in 1999. He encouraged freedom of the press. His presidency was plagued by various bloody conflicts, both long-running ones in Aceh and West Papua and new ones in Maluku, Poso (Sulawesi), and Kalimantan. There was a major financial scandal (Bank Bali case) related to his friends and the staff of his political party. On 1999, President BJ Habibie agreed to hold a referendum in East Timor. The result of the referendum was an overwhelming vote for independence from Indonesia. After the announcement of the result, there was a bloody riot in East Timor by the angry pro-Indonesia militia. The militia burned down houses, shops, schools, churches and government buildings. Hundreds of people were killed. The UN sent a peace keeping force to East Timor. The UN Human Rights Commission alleged that several Indonesian government staff and military officers were responsible for the riot. The Indonesian Human Rights Court freed all but one suspect. The only suspect punished for the human rights violation during the riot was Enrico Gutierrez, a former leader of the pro-Indonesia militia.

[TAB]Iran, officially the Islamic Republic of Iran and formerly known internationally as Persia until 1935, is a country in Central Eurasia,located on the northeastern shore of the Persian Gulf, northwestern shore of the Gulf of Oman, and the southern shore of the Caspian Sea. Both "Persia" and "Iran" are used interchangeably in cultural context; however, Iran is the name used officially in political context. The name Iran is a cognate of Aryan, and means "Land of the Aryans".[PARAGRAPH:2]Iran is home to one of the world's oldest continuous major civilizations, with historical and urban settlements dating back to 7000 BC. The first Iranian dynasty formed during the Elamite kingdom in 2800 BC. The Iranian Medes unified Iran into an empire in 625 BC. They were succeeded by three Iranian Empires, the Achaemenids, Parthians and Sassanids, which governed Iran for more than 1000 years. Iranian post-Islamic dynasties and empires expanded the Persian language and culture throughout the Iranian plateau. Early Iranian dynasties which re-asserted Iranian independence included the Tahirids, Saffarids, Samanids and Buyids. The blossoming of Persian literature, philosophy, medicine, astronomy, mathematics and art became major elements of Muslim civilization and started with the Saffarids and Samanids. Iran was once again reunified as an independent state in 1501 by the Safavid dynasty  who promoted Twelver Shi'a Islam as the official religion of their empire, marking one of the most important turning points in the history of Islam. "Persia's Constitutional Revolution" established the nation's first parliament in 1906, within a constitutional monarchy. Iran officially became an Islamic republic on 1 April 1979, following the Iranian Revolution.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Iranian Revolution, also known as the Islamic Revolution, began in January 1978 with the first major demonstrations against the Shah. After strikes and demonstrations paralysed the country and its economy, the Shah fled the country in January 1979 and Ayatollah Khomeini returned from exile to Tehran. The Pahlavi Dynasty collapsed ten days later, on 11 February, when Iran's military declared itself "neutral" after guerrillas and rebel troops overwhelmed troops loyal to the Shah in armed street fighting. Iran officially became an Islamic Republic on 1 April 1979 when Iranians overwhelmingly approved a national referendum to make it so. In December 1979, the country approved a theocratic constitution, whereby Khomeini became Supreme Leader of the country. The speed and success of the revolution surprised many throughout the world, as it had not been precipitated by a military defeat, a financial crisis, or a peasant rebellion. Although both nationalists and Marxists joined with Islamic traditionalists to overthrow the Shah, tens of thousands were killed and executed by the Islamic regime afterward, the revolution ultimately resulted in an Islamic Republic under Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.[PARAGRAPH:2]Following the IranIraq War President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani and his administration concentrated on a pragmatic pro-business policy of rebuilding and strengthening the economy without making any dramatic break with the ideology of the revolution. Rafsanjani served until 1997 when he was succeeded by the moderate reformist Mohammad Khatami. During his two terms as president, Khatami advocated freedom of expression, tolerance and civil society, constructive diplomatic relations with other states including EU and Asian governments, and an economic policy that supported free market and foreign investment. However, Khatami is widely regarded as having been unsuccessful in achieving his goal of making Iran more free and democratic. In the 2005 presidential elections, Iran made yet another change in political direction, when conservative populist candidate Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was elected over Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani.

[TAB]Iraq was home to the earliest known civilization on Earth, the Sumerian civilization, which arose in the fertile Tigris-Euphrates river valley of southern Iraq in the mid 6th millennium BC. It was here in the late 4th millennium BC, that the world's first writing system and recorded history itself were born. The Sumerian civilization flourished for over 3000 years and was succeeded by the rise of the Akkadian Empire in the 24th century BC. Over two centuries of Akkadian dominance was followed by a Sumerian Renaissance in the 21st century BC. An Elamite invasion in 2004 BC brought the Third Dynasty of Ur to an end. By the 18th century BC a new civilization, Babylonia, had risen to dominance in central and southern Iraq while a contemporaneous civilization, Assyria, had formed in northern Iraq.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Islamic conquest in the 7th century CE established Islam in Iraq. Under the Rashidun Caliphate, the prophet Mohammed's cousin and son-in-law Ali moved his capital to Kufa "fi al-Iraq" when he became the fourth caliph. The Umayyad Caliphate ruled the province of Iraq from Damascus in the 7th century. (However, eventually there was a separate, independent Caliphate of Cordoba.) The Abbasid Caliphate built the city of Baghdad in the 8th century as their capital, and it became the leading metropolis of the Arab and Muslim world for five centuries. Baghdad was the largest multicultural city of the Middle Ages, peaking at a population of more than a million, and was the centre of learning during the Islamic Golden Age. The Mongols destroyed the city during the sack of Baghdad in the 13th century.[PARAGRAPH:2]At the end of World War I, the League of Nations granted the area to the United Kingdom as a mandate. It initially formed two former Ottoman vilayets (regions): Baghdad and Basra into a single country in August 1921. Five years later, in 1926, the northern vilayet of Mosul was added, forming the territorial boundaries of the modern Iraqi state. Britain granted independence to Iraq in 1932, on the urging of King Faisal, though the British retained military bases and transit rights for their forces. King Ghazi of Iraq ruled as a figurehead after King Faisal's death in 1933, while undermined by attempted military coups, until his death in 1939. The United Kingdom invaded Iraq in 1941 (see Anglo-Iraqi War), for fear that the government of Rashid Ali al-Gaylani might cut oil supplies to Western nations, and because of his links to the Axis powers. A military occupation followed the restoration of the Hashemite monarchy, and the occupation ended on October 26, 1947.[PARAGRAPH:2]The reinstated Hashemite monarchy lasted until 1958, when it was overthrown by a coup d'etat of the Iraqi Army, known as the 14 July Revolution. The coup brought Brigadier General Abdul Karim Qassim to power. He withdrew from the Baghdad Pact and established friendly relations with the Soviet Union, but his government lasted only until the February 1963 coup, when it was overthrown by Colonel Abdul Salam Arif. Salam Arif died in 1966 and his brother, Abdul Rahman Arif, assumed the presidency. In 1968, Rahman Arif was overthrown by the Arab Socialist Baath Party. Ahmed Hasan Al-Bakir became the first Baath President of Iraq but then the movement gradually came under the control of Saddam Hussein al Tikriti, who acceded to the presidency and control of the Revolutionary Command Council (RCC), then Iraq's supreme executive body, in July 1979.[PARAGRAPH:2]Beginning with the invasion in 2003, a multinational coalition of forces, mainly American and British, occupied Iraq. Under the Laws of War and UNSCR 1483, the occupying Coalition Provisional Authority completed the transfer of sovereignty on June 28, 2004 to the Iraqi Interim Government in accordance with UNSCR 1546, formally ending the "occupation." Elections on January 30, 2005 created the Iraqi Transitional Government, which drafted the Constitution of Iraq, approved by referendum on October 25, 2005. Under this new Constitution, elections chose a new Iraqi National Assembly to form the Government of Iraq. Some dispute whether Iraq is de facto sovereign.

[TAB]Most people call the arrival of the Celts the beginning of Irish history. However, earlier peoples inhabited the land known as Ireland. Beautiful gold jewelry and pottery have been preserved to reveal their artistic skills. Their religious beliefs and practices are indicated in the decoration of their burial sites. The Celts came from Gaul, modern day France, around the 4th century BC. They dominate the people inhabiting the land with their iron swords. They developed an exact code of laws and honored their poets as much as kings. In the 5th century, St. Patrick came to Ireland and converted the people to Christianity. As a result, many monasteries were built and Irish monks brought Christianity into Europe. Because of Ireland's religious importance, it was also known as the Island of Saints and Scholars. However, a series of insignificant kings made strong governments impossible, leaving Ireland susceptible to various invaders. [PARAGRAPH: 2] The first invaders of Ireland were the Viking sailors from northern Europe. They founded many of the coastal cities of Ireland, which have been known throughout history as the most important. Dublin, Cork, and Limerick all owe their establishment to the Vikings, who first struck around the early 9th century. They remained in control of Ireland for several centuries. However, they had little power in the famous Battle of Clontarf, near Dublin. In this battle, the Irish king Brian Boru won a decisive victory in 1014. [PARAGRAPH: 2] The Kings of England had long been aware of the island to the west. In 1169, the Norman barons came to Ireland, lead by King Henry II of England, and forced the Gaelic kings to submit. They were used to the loose power of the Irish High King and were eager to shift their loyalty to England. England tightened its grip over the years, causing many Irish people to lose their cultural identity and adapt to England. The English colonists in Ireland spoke English and Norman French rather than Gaelic. In time, they began to intermarry with the Irish and accept their traditions. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Laws were passed to keep the English and Irish apart in 1366. It became illegal for the English to intermarry with the Irish. After the Protestant Reformation in the 16th century, the feelings of antagonism turned into a spiritual war. Henry VIII wanted the Catholics of Ireland to follow the Church of England. His daughter Queen Elizabeth I took land in Ireland and gave it to English settlers. A part of it was given to Sir Walter Raleigh who, according to legend, planted the first potato in Ireland. The Irish resisted the English stalwartly on several instances. The great Hugh O'Neill rallied the Irish forces and won victories during a nine year war. The Battle of Kinsale in 1601 was one of the decisive battles in Ireland's history, but ended in defeat of the Irish. Oliver Cromwell, the Puritan leader of England, finally crushed the Irish resistance during mid-17th century. He filled the entire country with British settlers and forced Catholic tenants to move to less fertile lands. Irish Catholics were allowed to keep only a third of all the land in Ireland. [PARAGRAPH: 2] However, a new hope befell the Irish after a Catholic king, James II, came to power in England. However, the Protestant English nobles offered the throne to the Protestant William III. As a result of the Catholic's opposition to William, the English Parliament passed the Penal Laws. These laws stated that the Irish Catholics had no legal or religious rights and were reduced into poverty. The French and American revolutions seemed to indicate a new era of liberty. Two attempted rebellions, one in 1798 and the other in 1803, both failed. However, an Act of Union stated Ireland would be part of the United Kingdom and Irish Catholics were promised seats in the British Parliament. The latter, however, was denied by King George III. Not until 1829 was this law repealed that denied the Catholics representation in Parliament. [PARAGRAPH: 2] The famine of 1845-49 brought new troubles to Ireland. It reduced the population by 2,500,000. About 1,500,000 died of disease and hunger, while the other portion moved to the United States and other countries. Home Rule became a popular demand, which was carried out by Charles Stewart Parnell. However, he lost his following when he was involved in a divorce case. During World War I, many Irish people joined the British army, while other joined the Irish volunteers, a group formed to defend the rights of the Irish people. In 1916, volunteers joined the Citizen Army, formed for the defense of the workers after the great Dublin strike in1913. The group attempted to capture Dublin and proclaim an Irish republic. However, they were forced to surrender to the British after several of the group's important leaders were shot. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Despite these setbacks, the Irish people still had their minds set on independence. After a war in 1921, Britain and Ireland signed a treaty by which twenty-six counties became a free state in the British Commonwealth. Six of the counties of Ulster remained apart as Northern Ireland, a province of the United Kingdom. Wars broke out between the supporters and opponents of the treaty. The opposition was lead by Eamon de Valera, who was elected president of the Republic in 1918. A new constitution was drawn up in 1936, and the country was to be ruled by a president and a prime minister. In 1948, Ireland was set up and left the Commonwealth. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Irish nationalists have always been opposed the partition of the country. In fact, the Irish constitution grants citizenship in the republic to the people of Northern Ireland. The Catholics of Northern Ireland feel they are discriminated against. Still, the Protestants in Ireland, the majority, are afraid they will be absorbed by the Catholics to the south. The problems created by the partition have lead to years of aggression and strife. In order to settle the dispute, the Irish government signed a treaty with the United Kingdom that stated that the Irish government had an advisory role in setting up the policy of Northern Ireland. In 1995, the Irish and British set up a structure for consultations in Northern Ireland, with the provision that the province's future would be determined by the people.
TEXT.French: [TAB] La plupart des gens appellent à l'arrivée des Celtes le début de l'histoire irlandaise. Toutefois, plus tôt les peuples de la terre habitée connue sous le nom de l'Irlande. Beaux bijoux en or et poteries ont été conservés à révéler leurs talents artistiques. Leurs croyances et pratiques religieuses sont indiqués dans la décoration de leurs lieux de sépulture. Les Celtes venaient de la Gaule, de la France des temps modernes, autour de la 4 e siècle av. Elles dominent les personnes vivant dans la terre avec leurs épées en fer. Ils ont mis au point un code exact des lois et honoré leurs poètes autant que rois. Dans le 5ème siècle, Saint Patrick est venu à l'Irlande et le peuple converti au christianisme. En conséquence, de nombreux monastères ont été construits et des moines irlandais porté le christianisme dans l'Europe. En raison de l'importance religieuse de l'Irlande, il était également connu sous le nom de l'île des saints et des érudits. Toutefois, une série de faits insignifiants rois forte gouvernements impossible de quitter l'Irlande sensibles aux divers envahisseurs. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Le premier envahisseurs de l'Irlande étaient les vikings marins de l'Europe du Nord. Ils ont créé un grand nombre de villes côtières de l'Irlande, qui ont été connus dans l'histoire comme le plus important. Dublin, Cork, Limerick et tous doivent leur établissement pour les Vikings, qui, le premier, frappé dans le 9ème siècle tôt. Ils sont restés dans le contrôle de l'Irlande pendant plusieurs siècles. Toutefois, ils ont peu de pouvoir dans la célèbre bataille de Clontarf, près de Dublin. Dans cette bataille, le roi irlandais Brian Boru a remporté une victoire décisive en 1014. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Les Rois d'Angleterre est depuis longtemps conscient de l'île à l'ouest. En 1169, les barons de Norman est venu à l'Irlande, dirigée par le roi Henri II d'Angleterre, et a forcé le gaélique rois de présenter. Ils ont servi à desserrer la puissance de l'Irish High King et étaient impatients de passer leur loyauté à l'Angleterre. Angleterre resserré son emprise au fil des ans, causant de nombreux Irlandais de perdre leur identité culturelle et à s'adapter à l'Angleterre. Les colons anglais en Irlande parlaient anglais et le français plutôt que Norman gaélique. Dans le temps, ils ont commencé à intermarry avec les Irlandais et accepter leurs traditions. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Les lois ont été adoptées pour maintenir le gaélique et l'anglais en dehors de 1366. Il est devenu illégal pour les Anglais à intermarry avec le gaélique. Après la Réforme protestante au 16e siècle, les sentiments d'hostilité transformée en une guerre spirituelle. Henri VIII voulait les catholiques de l'Irlande pour suivre l'Église d'Angleterre. Sa fille, la Reine Elizabeth, j'ai pris des terres en Irlande et le donna aux colons anglais. Une partie de celle-ci a été accordée à Sir Walter Raleigh, qui, selon la légende, la première pomme de terre plantée en Irlande. Les Irlandais résisté à l'anglais stalwartly sur plusieurs cas. Le grand Hugh O'Neill rallia les forces et irlandais remporté des victoires pendant une durée de neuf ans de guerre. La bataille de Kinsale en 1601 a été l'une des batailles décisives dans l'histoire de l'Irlande, mais a terminé dans la défaite de l'irlandais. Oliver Cromwell, puritain dirigeant de l'Angleterre, a finalement écrasé la résistance irlandaise au milieu de 17e siècle. Il a comblé le pays tout entier avec des colons britanniques et catholiques locataires forcés de passer à des terres moins fertiles. Irlandais catholiques ont été autorisés à conserver un tiers seulement de l'ensemble des terres en Irlande. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Cependant, un nouvel espoir s'était abattue sur le irlandaise après un roi catholique, Jacques II, arrivé au pouvoir en Angleterre. Toutefois, les protestants anglais noblesse offert le trône à la protestante Guillaume III. À la suite de l'opposition des catholiques à William, le Parlement français a adopté la lois pénales. Ces lois a déclaré que les catholiques irlandais n'avait pas de droit ou de droits religieux et ont été réduits à la pauvreté. Les révolutions française et américaine semble indiquer une nouvelle ère de liberté. Deux tentatives de rébellions, l'une en 1798 et l'autre en 1803, à la fois échoué. Toutefois, une loi de l'Union a déclaré Irlande ferait partie du Royaume-Uni et des Irlandais catholiques ont promis des sièges dans le Parlement britannique. Cette dernière, cependant, a été rejetée par le roi George III. Ce n'est qu'en 1829 a été abrogé cette loi qui nie les catholiques représentation au Parlement. [PARAGRAPH: 2] La famine de 1845-49 a introduit de nouveaux problèmes à l'Irlande. Elle réduit la population par 2500000. A propos 1500000 mortes de la maladie et la faim, tandis que l'autre partie pour les États-Unis et d'autres pays. Home Rule est devenue une demande populaire, qui a été réalisée par Charles Stewart Parnell. Toutefois, il a perdu son suivant quand il a été impliqué dans une affaire de divorce. Durant la Première Guerre mondiale, de nombreux citoyens irlandais a rejoint l'armée britannique, alors que d'autres sont joints aux bénévoles irlandais, un groupe formé pour défendre les droits du peuple irlandais. En 1916, les bénévoles se sont associés à la Citizen Army, formée pour la défense des travailleurs de Dublin après la grande grève in1913. Le groupe a tenté de capturer Dublin et proclamer une république irlandaise. Toutefois, ils ont dû se rendre à la British après plusieurs des importants dirigeants du groupe ont été fusillés. [PARAGRAPH: 2] En dépit de ces revers, le peuple irlandais avait encore fixés sur leur esprit d'indépendance. Après une guerre en 1921, la Grande-Bretagne et l'Irlande signent un traité par lequel vingt et six comtés devenu un état libre dans le Commonwealth britannique. Six des comtés de l'Ulster est restée en dehors de l'Irlande du Nord, une province du Royaume-Uni. Les guerres ont éclaté entre les partisans et les adversaires du traité. L'opposition était dirigée par Seán Lemass, qui a été élu président de la République en 1918. Une nouvelle constitution a été rédigée en 1936, et le pays devait être gouverné par un président et un premier ministre. En 1948, l'Irlande a été mis en place et a quitté le Commonwealth. [PARAGRAPH: 2] nationalistes irlandais ont toujours été opposés à la partition du pays. En fait, la constitution irlandaise accorde la citoyenneté dans la République à la population de l'Irlande du Nord. Les catholiques d'Irlande du Nord se sentent victimes de discrimination. Pourtant, les protestants, en Irlande, en majorité, ont peur, ils seront absorbés par les catholiques du sud. Les problèmes créés par la partition ont conduit à des années de troubles et de l'agression. Afin de régler le différend, le gouvernement irlandais a signé un traité avec le Royaume-Uni, qui a déclaré que le gouvernement irlandais avait un rôle consultatif dans la mise en place de la politique de l'Irlande du Nord. En 1995, l'irlandais et britanniques mis en place une structure pour les consultations en Irlande du Nord, étant entendu que l'avenir de la province devrait être déterminé par le peuple.
TEXT.German: [TAB] Die meisten Menschen rufen der Ankunft der Kelten den Beginn der irischen Geschichte. Aber ältere Menschen bewohnte das Land bekannt als Irland. Schöne Goldschmuck und Töpferei wurden erhalten, um ihre künstlerischen Fähigkeiten. Ihrer religiösen Überzeugungen und Praktiken sind in der Dekoration ihrer Grabstätten. Die Kelten aus Gallien, modernen Frankreich, um das 4. Jahrhundert v. Chr.. Sie beherrschen die Menschen das Land bewohnen mit ihren Schwertern Eisen. Sie entwickelten eine exakte Code von Gesetzen und ihre Dichter geehrt so viel wie Könige. Im 5. Jahrhundert, kam St. Patrick nach Irland und konvertiert die Menschen zum Christentum. Als Folge sind viele Klöster wurden gebaut und irischen Mönche brachten das Christentum in Europa. Weil der irischen religiöse Bedeutung, es war auch bekannt als die Insel der Heiligen und Wissenschaftler. Allerdings ist eine Reihe von unbedeutenden Könige, die starke Regierungen unmöglich, so dass Irland anfällig für verschiedene Eindringlinge. [ABSATZ: 2] Die ersten Eindringlinge von Irland waren die Wikinger Segler aus dem Norden Europas. Sie gründeten viele der Küstenstädte von Irland, die sich im Laufe der Geschichte ist bekannt als das wichtigste. Dublin, Cork, Limerick und alle verdanken ihre Gründung der Wikinger, die erste fiel in der frühen 9. Jahrhundert. Sie blieb bei der Kontrolle von Irland für mehrere Jahrhunderte. Allerdings hatten sie wenig Energie in der berühmten Schlacht bei Clontarf, in der Nähe von Dublin. In diesem Kampf, der irische König Brian Boru gewann einen entscheidenden Sieg in 1014. [ABSATZ: 2] Die Könige von England schon seit langem bekannt, der Insel im Westen. In 1169, der normannischen Barone kam nach Irland, die von König Heinrich II. von England, und zwang die Gälisch Könige vorzulegen. Sie wurden verwendet, um die losen Macht des irischen High King und waren begierig zu verlagern ihre Loyalität zu England. England verschärft ihren Halt im Laufe der Jahre, so dass viele irische Volk zu verlieren ihre kulturelle Identität und der Anpassung an England. Die englische Kolonisten in Irland Norman sprach Englisch und Französisch als Fremdsprachen. In der Zeit, sie begann zu intermarry mit der irischen und ihre Traditionen. [ABSATZ: 2] Gesetze verabschiedet, um die englischen und irischen auseinander 1366. Es wurde für die illegale Englisch intermarry mit der irischen. Nachdem die protestantische Reformation im 16. Jahrhundert, die Gefühle der Antagonismus zu einem spirituellen Krieg. Heinrich VIII. wollte, dass die Katholiken in Irland, um die Kirche von England. Seine Tochter Königin Elizabeth Ich habe Land und in Irland gab es auf Englisch Siedler. Ein Teil davon wurde von Sir Walter Raleigh, die nach der Legende, pflanzten die ersten Kartoffeln in Irland. Die irische Widerstand der englischen stalwartly über mehrere Instanzen. Die große Hugh O'Neill Truppen der irischen Streitkräfte und gewann Siege bei einem neun Jahre Krieg. Die Schlacht von Kinsale im 1601 war eine der entscheidenden Schlachten in Irland's Geschichte, sondern endete mit einer Niederlage der Iren. Oliver Cromwell, der Führer der puritanischen England, schließlich zerkleinert der irischen Widerstand in der Mitte des 17. Jahrhunderts. Er füllte das ganze Land mit dem britischen Siedler und gezwungen katholischen Mieter, um weniger fruchtbare Land. Katholiken durften immer nur ein Drittel der Flächen in Irland. [ABSATZ: 2] jedoch eine neue Hoffnung widerfuhr der irischen nach einem katholischen König Jakob II., an die Macht kam England. Allerdings ist die protestantische englische Adel bot den Thron an die protestantische Wilhelm III. Als Ergebnis der katholischen der Opposition an William, in der englischen Parlament das Strafgesetzbuch verankert. Diese Gesetze erklärt, dass die irischen Katholiken hatten keine rechtlichen oder religiösen Rechte und reduziert wurden in die Armut. Die amerikanischen und französischen Revolutionen schien, um eine neue Ära der Freiheit. Zwei Aufstände versucht, eine in 1798 und die andere in 1803, die beide scheiterten. Es gibt jedoch ein Gesetz der Union erklärt, Irland wäre Teil des Vereinigten Königreichs und der irischen Katholiken wurden versprochen Sitze im britischen Parlament. Letzteres war jedoch verweigert von König Georg III. Erst 1829 wurde dieses Gesetz aufgehoben, verweigert den Katholiken Vertretung im Parlament. [ABSATZ: 2] Die Hungersnot von 1845-49 führte zu neuen Unruhen in Irland. Es reduziert die Bevölkerung von 2500000. Über 1500000 starb an Krankheit und Hunger, während der andere Teil in den Vereinigten Staaten und anderen Ländern. Home Rule wurde zu einem beliebten Nachfrage, die von Charles Stewart Parnell. Allerdings verlor er seinen folgenden, wenn er sich im Falle einer Scheidung. Während des Ersten Weltkrieges, viele Iren trat der britischen Armee, während andere bei der irischen Freiwilligen, eine Gruppe, die zur Verteidigung der Rechte des irischen Volkes. In 1916, Freiwillige in die Armee Bürger, die für die Verteidigung der Arbeitnehmer nach dem großen Dublin Streik in1913. Die Gruppe versucht zu erfassen Dublin und verkünden einer irischen Republik. Allerdings waren sie gezwungen, zum Verzicht auf die britische nach mehreren der in der Gruppe ist wichtig, Führer geschossen. [ABSATZ: 2] Trotz dieser Rückschläge, die Iren noch ihre Köpfe auf Unabhängigkeit. Nach einem Krieg in 1921, Großbritannien und Irland einen Vertrag, durch die sechsundzwanzig Grafschaften zu einem freien Staat im britischen Commonwealth. Sechs der Grafschaften von Ulster blieb neben als Nordirland, eine Provinz des Vereinigten Königreichs. Kriege ausgebrochen zwischen den Befürwortern und den Gegnern des Vertrages. Die Opposition war der Führung von Eamon de Valera, wurde zum Präsidenten der Republik in 1918. Eine neue Verfassung wurde in 1936, und das Land wurde zu sein, die von einem Präsidenten und einem Ministerpräsidenten. In 1948, Irland gegründet wurde und aus dem Commonwealth. [ABSATZ: 2] irischen Nationalisten haben immer gegen die Teilung des Landes. In der Tat, die irische Verfassung gewährt Staatsbürgerschaft in der Republik für die Menschen in Nordirland. Die Katholiken in Nordirland das Gefühl, dass sie diskriminiert werden. Noch, die Protestanten in Irland, in der Mehrheit, die Angst werden sie von den Katholiken in den Süden. Die Probleme, die durch die Partition, die zum Jahr der Aggression und Streit. Im Hinblick auf die Streitigkeit, die irische Regierung unterzeichnete einen Vertrag mit dem Vereinigten Königreich, erklärte, dass die irische Regierung hatte eine beratende Rolle bei der Festlegung der Politik in Nordirland. In 1995, die irische und die britische Einrichtung einer Struktur für Konsultationen in Nordirland, mit der Bestimmung, dass die Provinz für die Zukunft wäre, die durch den Menschen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB] La maggior parte delle persone chiama l'arrivo dei Celti l'inizio della storia irlandese. Tuttavia, prima popoli della terra abitata noto come l'Irlanda. Bella oro e gioielli di ceramica sono stati conservati a rivelare la loro capacità artistiche. Il loro credo religioso e delle pratiche sono indicati nella decorazione della loro sepoltura siti. Celti provenienti da Gallia, Francia moderna giorni, intorno al 4 ° secolo aC. Essi dominano le popolazioni della terra con le loro spade in ferro. Essi hanno messo a punto un preciso codice di leggi e la loro onorati poeti tanto come re. Nel 5 ° secolo, è venuto a San Patrizio Irlanda e la gente convertiti al cristianesimo. Di conseguenza, molti monasteri sono stati costruiti e monaci irlandesi portarono il cristianesimo in Europa. Perché di importanza religiosa Irlanda, è stata conosciuta anche come l'Isola dei Santi e studiosi. Tuttavia, una serie di insignificanti re reso impossibile governi forti, lasciando Irlanda soggetta a vari invasori. [PARAGRAFO: 2] Il primo invasori d'Irlanda sono stati i marinai Viking dal nord Europa. Hanno fondato molte delle città costiere dell'Irlanda, che hanno conosciuto nel corso della storia come la più importante. Dublino, Cork, Limerick e tutti devono la loro istituzione ai Vichinghi, che per primo ha colpito intorno ai primi 9a secolo. Essi rimase in Irlanda per il controllo di diversi secoli. Tuttavia, non avevano il potere nella famosa battaglia di Clontarf, vicino a Dublino. In questa battaglia, il re irlandese Brian Boru vinto una decisiva vittoria nel 1014. [PARAGRAFO: 2] Il re d'Inghilterra era stato a lungo a conoscenza dell 'isola ad ovest. Nel 1169, i baroni normanni è venuto in Irlanda, il piombo dal re Enrico II d'Inghilterra, e il gaelico re costretti a presentare. Essi sono stati utilizzati per l'alimentazione di perdere l'Irish High King e sono ansioso di spostare la loro lealtà in Inghilterra. Inghilterra rafforzato la sua presa nel corso degli anni, causando molti popolo irlandese, a perdere la loro identità culturale e adattare in Inghilterra. L'inglese coloni in Irlanda ha parlato in inglese e francese, piuttosto che di Norman gaelico. Nel tempo, hanno cominciato a intermarry con l'irlandese e di accettare le loro tradizioni. [PARAGRAFO: 2] è stata approvata una legge per mantenere l'inglese e irlandese oltre nel 1366. Essa divenne illegale per l'inglese a intermarry con gli irlandesi. Dopo la Riforma protestante nel 16 ° secolo, i sentimenti di antagonismo trasformata in una guerra spirituale. Enrico VIII voleva i cattolici d'Irlanda, a seguire la Chiesa d'Inghilterra. Sua figlia, la regina Elisabetta mi ha preso terra in Irlanda e lo diede ai coloni inglese. Una parte di esso è stata data a Sir Walter Raleigh, che, secondo la leggenda, piantata la prima patata in Irlanda. L'irlandese resistito inglese stalwartly su diversi casi. La grande mobilitazione Hugh O'Neill irlandese forze e ha vinto nove vittorie nel corso di un anno di guerra. La battaglia di Kinsale nel 1601 è stata una delle battaglie decisive della storia in Irlanda, ma si è conclusa nella sconfitta dei irlandese. Oliver Cromwell, il leader del puritana Inghilterra, infine schiacciato la resistenza irlandese, durante la metà del 17 ° secolo. Egli ha riempito l'intero paese con British coloni affittuari cattolica e costretto a trasferirsi in meno fertili terre. Irlandesi cattolici sono stati autorizzati a mantenere solo un terzo di tutti i terreni in Irlanda. [PARAGRAFO: 2] Tuttavia, una nuova speranza accaduto dopo un irlandese cattolico re, Giacomo II, salito al potere in Inghilterra. Tuttavia, il protestante inglese nobili offerto il trono al protestante Guglielmo III. Come risultato della Cattolica di opposizione a William, il Parlamento inglese ha approvato la legge penale. Queste leggi ha affermato che gli irlandesi cattolici non aveva diritto o di diritti religiosi e sono stati ridotti in povertà. Le rivoluzioni francese e americana sembrava indicare una nuova era di libertà. Due tentativi di ribellioni, uno nel 1798 el'altro nel 1803, entrambi falliti. Tuttavia, un atto di Unione sarebbe dichiarato Irlanda parte del Regno Unito e irlandese, i cattolici erano stati promessi seggi nel Parlamento britannico. Quest'ultimo, tuttavia, è stato negato dal re Giorgio III. Non fino al 1829 è stata abrogata la legge che ha negato i cattolici rappresentanza in Parlamento. [PARAGRAFO: 2] La carestia del 1845-49 ha portato nuovi problemi per l'Irlanda. Ha ridotto la popolazione da 2500000. Chi 1500000 morto di malattia e la fame, mentre l'altra parte si trasferì negli Stati Uniti e in altri paesi. Regola divenne una casa popolare domanda, che è stata effettuata da Charles Stewart Parnell. Tuttavia, ha perso il suo seguito, quando è stato coinvolto in un caso di divorzio. Durante la prima guerra mondiale, molte persone hanno aderito irlandese britannico, mentre altri hanno aderito irlandese volontari, un gruppo costituito per difendere i diritti del popolo irlandese. Nel 1916, i volontari hanno aderito Cittadino Esercito, costituito per la difesa dei lavoratori dopo la grande Dublino sciopero in1913. Il gruppo ha tentato di catturare Dublino e proclamare uno repubblica irlandese. Tuttavia, essi sono stati costretti a rinunciare al British dopo diversi del gruppo di importanti dirigenti sono stati girati. [PARAGRAFO: 2] Nonostante questi contrattempi, il popolo irlandese ha ancora fissato le loro menti in materia di indipendenza. Dopo la guerra nel 1921, la Gran Bretagna e Irlanda firmato un trattato che da ventisei contee diventato uno Stato libero nel Commonwealth britannico. Sei delle contee di Ulster rimasto oltre Irlanda del Nord, una provincia del Regno Unito. Guerre sono scoppiati tra sostenitori e oppositori del Trattato. L'opposizione era guidata da Eamon di Valera, che è stato eletto presidente della Repubblica nel 1918. Una nuova costituzione è stata redatta nel 1936, e il paese doveva essere governato da un presidente e un primo ministro. Nel 1948, l'Irlanda è stato istituito e ha lasciato il Commonwealth. [PARAGRAFO: 2] nazionalisti irlandesi sono sempre stati contrari alla partizione del paese. Di fatto, la costituzione irlandese borse di cittadinanza nella repubblica per il popolo dell'Irlanda del Nord. I cattolici dell'Irlanda del Nord si sentono discriminati. Ancora, i protestanti in Irlanda, la maggioranza, hanno paura che saranno assorbiti dai cattolici a sud. I problemi creati dalla partizione hanno portato ad anni di aggressione e di lotte. Al fine di risolvere la controversia, il governo irlandese ha firmato un trattato con il Regno Unito, che ha dichiarato che il governo irlandese ha avuto un ruolo consultivo nella messa in funzione della politica dell'Irlanda del Nord. Nel 1995, l'irlandese e britannico istituito una struttura per le consultazioni in Irlanda del Nord, con la disposizione che la provincia del futuro sarebbe determinato dal popolo.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB] La mayoría de la gente llame a la llegada de los celtas el comienzo de la historia irlandesa. Sin embargo, a principios de los pueblos de la tierra habitada conocido como Irlanda. Beautiful joyas de oro y cerámica se han conservado a revelar sus habilidades artísticas. Sus creencias y prácticas religiosas están indicados en la decoración de sus lugares de enterramiento. Los celtas vinieron de la Galia, Francia moderna, en torno a los 4 º siglo BC. Ellos dominan los pueblos que habitan la tierra con sus espadas de hierro. Se elaboró un código exacto de las leyes y el honor de sus poetas tanto como reyes. En el 5 º siglo, de San Patricio llegó a Irlanda y el pueblo convertido al cristianismo. Como resultado de ello, muchos monasterios fueron construidos y monjes irlandeses trajo el cristianismo en Europa. Debido a la importancia religiosa de Irlanda, es también conocida como la Isla de los Santos y erudita. Sin embargo, una serie de reyes insignificante hecho fuertes gobiernos imposible, dejando Irlanda susceptibles a diversos invasores. [APARTADO: 2] Los primeros invasores de Irlanda fueron las Viking marineros del norte de Europa. Fundaron muchas de las ciudades costeras de Irlanda, que se han conocido a través de la historia como la más importante. Dublín, Cork, Limerick y todos deben su creación a los vikingos, que primero golpeó en torno a la pronta siglo 9. Ellos permanecieron en el control de Irlanda durante varios siglos. Sin embargo, tienen poco poder en la famosa batalla de Clontarf, cerca de Dublín. En esta batalla, el rey irlandés Brian Boru ganaron una victoria decisiva en 1014. [APARTADO: 2] Los reyes de Inglaterra, durante mucho tiempo ha sido consciente de la isla al oeste. En 1169, los barones normandos llegaron a Irlanda, el plomo por el rey Enrique II de Inglaterra, y obligó a los reyes que le presente el gaélico. Estos recursos se utilizaron para la suelta poder de los irlandeses Alto Rey y estaban deseosos de cambiar su lealtad a Inglaterra. Inglaterra reforzado su control a través de los años, haciendo que muchos irlandeses a perder su identidad cultural y adaptarse a Inglaterra. Los colonos Inglés en Irlanda habla Inglés y francés en lugar de Norman gaélico. Con el tiempo, comenzaron a intermarry con el irlandés y aceptar sus tradiciones. [APARTADO: 2] Las leyes se aprobaron para mantener el Inglés y aparte de Irlanda en 1366. Se convirtió en ilegales para el Inglés a intermarry con el irlandés. Después de la reforma protestante en el siglo 16, los sentimientos de antagonismo se convirtió en una guerra espiritual. Enrique VIII quería los católicos de Irlanda de seguir la Iglesia de Inglaterra. Su hija de la Reina Isabel I tomó tierra en Irlanda y lo dio a los colonos Inglés. Una parte de ella se dio a Sir Walter Raleigh que, según la leyenda, plantaron el primer papa en Irlanda. El irlandés resistido el Inglés stalwartly en varios casos. La gran Hugh O'Neill unieron fuerzas y el irlandés ganó victorias durante nueve años de guerra. La batalla de Kinsale en 1601 fue una de las batallas decisivas en la historia de Irlanda, pero terminó en derrota de los irlandeses. Oliver Cromwell, el Puritan líder de Inglaterra, finalmente aplastada la resistencia irlandesa durante la mitad del siglo 17. Él llena todo el país con los colonos británicos y de los inquilinos forzados Católica de pasar a las tierras menos fértiles. Católicos irlandeses les permitía conservar un tercio de toda la tierra de Irlanda. [APARTADO: 2] Sin embargo, una nueva esperanza que le ocurrió a los irlandeses después de un rey católico, James II, llegó al poder en Inglaterra. Sin embargo, los protestantes Inglés nobleza ofreció el trono a la protestante Guillermo III. Como resultado de la oposición de los católicos a William, el Parlamento Inglés aprobó la Ley Penal. Estas leyes se indica que los irlandeses católicos no tenían derechos legales o religiosos y se redujeron en la pobreza. Las revoluciones americana y francesa parece indicar una nueva era de libertad. Dos intentos de rebeliones, uno en 1798 y otro en 1803, ambos fracasaron. Sin embargo, una ley de la Unión declaró Irlanda sería parte del Reino Unido y de Irlanda católicos se les prometió escaños en el Parlamento británico. Este último, sin embargo, fue denegada por el rey Jorge III. No fue hasta 1829 se derogó esta ley que niega la representación de los católicos en el Parlamento. [APARTADO: 2] La hambruna de 1845-49 traído nuevos problemas a Irlanda. Se redujo la población por 2500000. Sobre 1500000 murió de la enfermedad y el hambre, mientras que la otra parte se trasladó a los Estados Unidos y otros países. Inicio de Regla se convirtió en una demanda popular, que se llevó a cabo por Charles Stewart Parnell. Sin embargo, perdió su siguiente cuando él estaba involucrado en un caso de divorcio. Durante la Primera Guerra Mundial, muchas personas se unieron a la de Irlanda del ejército británico, mientras que otros se sumaron a los voluntarios irlandeses, un grupo formado para defender los derechos del pueblo irlandés. En 1916, los voluntarios se sumaron a los Ciudadanos Ejército, formado para la defensa de los trabajadores después de la gran Dublin huelga in1913. El grupo trató de la captura de Dublín y proclamar un irlandés república. Sin embargo, se vieron obligados a rendirse a los británicos después de varios de los importantes dirigentes del grupo fueron fusilados. [APARTADO: 2] A pesar de estos reveses, el pueblo irlandés todavía había fijan la mente en la independencia. Después de una guerra en 1921, Gran Bretaña e Irlanda firmaron un tratado por el cual vigésimo seis condados se convirtió en un estado libre en la Commonwealth británica. Seis de los condados de Ulster subsistieron, como Irlanda del Norte, una provincia del Reino Unido. Guerra de las Galaxias estalló entre los partidarios y los opositores del tratado. La oposición fue liderada por Eamon de Valera, quien fue elegido presidente de la República en 1918. Una nueva constitución fue redactada en 1936, y el país iba a ser gobernado por un presidente y un primer ministro. En 1948, Irlanda se creó la Comunidad y de la izquierda. [APARTADO: 2] Irish nacionalistas siempre se han opuesto a la partición del país. De hecho, la Constitución irlandesa concede la ciudadanía en la república a la gente de Irlanda del Norte. Los católicos de Irlanda del Norte se sienten discriminados. Sin embargo, los protestantes en Irlanda, la mayoría, tienen miedo de que será absorbida por los católicos hacia el sur. Los problemas creados por la partición que han llevado a años de la agresión y los conflictos. Con el fin de resolver la controversia, el gobierno irlandés firmó un tratado con el Reino Unido, que dijo que el gobierno irlandés tiene una función de asesoramiento en el establecimiento de la política de Irlanda del Norte. En 1995, el irlandés y británico creó una estructura para la celebración de consultas en Irlanda del Norte, con la disposición de que el futuro de la provincia se determinaría por el pueblo.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Israel is a small nation in the Middle East, located in Southwest Asia on the edge of the Mediterranean Sea. The State of Israel was established in 1948 as a refuge for Jews worldwide. The founders of the modern state of Israel sought to create a new country whose principles, customs, and way of life would be Jewish. [PARAGRAPH: 2] Jewish kingdoms flourished in the region in ancient times, but before 1948, there had been no Jewish state for 2,000 years. The Jews were scattered all over the world after the Romans had driven them out in the first and second centuries AD. Despite all this oppression, the Jews never forgot the Land of Israel. The Jews are closely connected with the Land of Israel because of all of the religious events that occurred in Israel. There were also very important events in history in Israel, such as the destruction of the temple and the rise and fall of Jewish kingdoms. When Jews were persecuted in the Middle Ages, it was the hope of returning to Israel that kept them alive. [PARAGRAPH: 2] The Exodus out of Egypt, lead by Moses, lead the Hebrews to the ancient Land of Israel. The Philistines forced the Hebrews to unite under a single leader, Saul, who lead the Hebrews to victory over the Philistines. Saul is usually regarded as the first Hebrew king. Saul was followed by King David. David was a hero from childhood, when he had slain eyed the lion-beast Goliath. David declared Jerusalem the capital, and created a powerful military. David also brought the Ark of the Covenant to Jerusalem, which contained two stone tablets on which the Ten Commandments were written. Solomon followed David. Solomon was a master diplomat, who builds roads, fortresses, and a royal palace. Most famous is SolomonÂs temple, known as the Temple of Solomon. The Temple of Solomon was the center of Jewish religion in that time [PARAGRAPH: 2] High taxes in Israel lead to the division of the kingdom. The north, Israel, carried most of the population and territory. The small and southern portion became Judah. Israel survived for two centuries. It was destroyed internally, and was caught by rival empires. At 734 BC, the Assyrians invaded Israel. They killed many Israelites and exiled many more. Judah, had less violence than Israel. In 586 BC, Jerusalem fell to the Babylonians and the Temple of Solomon was destroyed. But the Judeans refused to forget there homeland of Judah. The Judeans came together in gatherings that were the forerunner for synogogues. The listened to there prophets. When Cyrus the Great of Persia took control of Palestinian lands, he allowed the Judeans to return to there land. For 600 years, there was another Jewish state. [PARAGRAPH: 2] When the Judeans returned to Israel, the process of creating a new kingdom proved to be hard. There was religious troubles in Israel. Non-Jews were scorned in Judean society. New prophets had to teach that God was not only meant for the Jews, but all people. In the fourth century BC, Alexander the Great defeated the country. This brought in pagan customs to the land. Some youths even abandoned Jewish traditions. A later Greek ruler, Antiochus Epiphanes, persecuted the Jews and their traditions. Under Judah Maccabee and his brothers, a revolt flared. In 165, the Jewish state was independent once again.[PARAGRAPH: 2] In the first century BC, Rome conquered the Jewish State. RomeÂs rule was tyrannical, and a Jewish revolt began in 66 AD. The Roman legions conquered Jerusalem after a long resistance in 70 AD. The Romans destroyed the temple, and all that remained was the wall. This wall became known as the Wailing Wall, and is the holiest place for prayer for the Jews today. In 73 AD, the Romans conquered Masada, and the Jewish state was destroyed. The Jewish people were in exile. For many years, the Jews faced horrible punishment for being Jews during the Middle Ages. [PARAGRAPH: 2] In the 19th Century, waves of anti-Semitism spread across Eastern Europe, where many Jew lived. Many Jews emigrated to the United States and Europe. Some moved to Palestine, the location of the ancient Land of Israel. This idea of creating a new Jewish state is called Zionism. The Holocaust of World War II, when six million Jews were murdered, added to the intensity of the Zionist movement. The war also left many Jewish refugees in Europe. Many preferred to establish a new nation rather than move to new homes, or go back to their old country. [PARAGRAPH: 2] The United Nations noticed the need for a Jewish homeland, and in 1947, it recommended that Palestine be turned into a Jewish state. On May 14, 1948, David Ben-Gurion, IsraelÂs first prime minister, declared IsraelÂs independence. Many Arab countries opposed this decision, and this sparked the years of Arab-Israeli conflict that would come. Israel since has developed into a modern democracy, and is one of the most powerful countries in the Middle East.
